A Guide to Data Science

===========

@toc

This is a brief introduction to data science. Data science can be seen as an extension of statistics.

  •  All sciences are, in the abstract, mathematics.\color{aqua}{\text{ All sciences are, in the abstract, mathematics.}} All sciences are, in the abstract, mathematics.
  •  All judgments are, in their rationale, statistics. by C.P. Rao\color{aqua}{\text{ All judgments are, in their rationale, statistics. by C.P. Rao}} All judgments are, in their rationale, statistics. by C.P. Rao

On Chomsky and the Two Cultures of Statistical Learning or Statistical Modeling: The Two Cultures (with comments and a rejoinder by the author) provides more discussion of statistical model or data science.

Statistical Foundation

"Statistics, in a nutshell, is a discipline that studies the best ways of dealing with randomness, or more precisely and broadly, variation", Professor Xiao-Li Meng said.

On mathematical model

Basic Probability

Probability theory is regarded as the theoretical foundation of statistics, which provides the ideal models to measure the stochastic phenomenon, randomness, chance or luck. It is the distribution theory bridging probability and statistics. The project seeing theory is a brief introduction to statistics and probability theory and also a .pdf file.

  • https://nsf-tripods.org/institutes/

Random Variable

Random variable is to represent the stochastic event, where stochastic event is the event that may or may not happen with some known results.

Definition: A random variable is a mapping

X:Ω→R\color{green}{X:\Omega \rightarrow \mathbb{R}} X:Ω→R

that assigns a real number X(ω)X(\omega)X(ω) to each outcome ω\omegaω.

  • Ω\OmegaΩ is the sample space.
  • ω\omegaω in Ω\OmegaΩ are called sample outcomes or realization.
  • Subsets of Ω\OmegaΩ are called Event.

Probability

Probability is the mathematical measure to likelihood or chance.

Definition A function PPP is called probability function with respect to the known sample space Ω\OmegaΩ and all the event ∀ω∈Ω\forall \omega \in \Omega∀ω∈Ω if

Properties Conditions Interpretation
Nonnegative P(ω)≥0∀ω∈ΩP(\omega) \geq 0 \forall \omega \in \OmegaP(ω)≥0∀ω∈Ω Impossible = 0
Normalized P(Ω)=1P(\Omega) = 1P(Ω)=1 Something must happen
Additive If ω1,ω2,⋯∈Ω\omega_1, \omega_2, \cdots \in \Omegaω1​,ω2​,⋯∈Ω are disjoint, then P(⋃i=1∞ωi)=∑i=1∞P(ωi)P(\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}\omega_i)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(\omega_i)P(⋃i=1∞​ωi​)=∑i=1∞​P(ωi​) Do your own business

These properties are called Kolmogorov axioms^1.

Discrete Distribution

Random variable or event is countable or listed, then we can list the probability of every event. If so, we can compute the probability of a random variable less than the given value. For example, P(X≤10)=∑i=110P(X=i)P(X\leq 10)=\sum_{i=1}^{10}P(X=i)P(X≤10)=∑i=110​P(X=i) if the random variable XXX only takes positive integers.

What is more, there is a link of discrete distribution or more [^2].

Probability Mass Function

The probability mass function (pmf in short) of a discrete random variable XXX is defined as

Definition: The probability mass function of a discrete random variable XXX is defined as

fX(x)=PX(X=x)f_X(x)=P_X(X=x) fX​(x)=PX​(X=x)

for all xxx.

The left subindex X\mathrm{X}X is to point out that the probability is with respect to the random variable XXX and it can omit if no confusion.

Continuous Distribution

If random variables may take on a continuous range of values, it is hard or valueless to compute the probability of a given value. It is usually to find the cumulative distribution function.

Cumulative Distribution Function

Definition: A function F(x)F(x)F(x) is called cumulative distribution function (CDF in short) if

  • lim⁡x→−∞F(x)=0\lim_{x\to -\infty}F(x) = 0limx→−∞​F(x)=0 and lim⁡x→∞F(x)=1\lim_{x\to \infty}F(x) = 1limx→∞​F(x)=1 ;
  • The function F(x)F(x)F(x) is monotone increasing function with xxx;
  • lim⁡x→x0+F(x)=F(x0)\lim_{x\to x_0^+ } F(x) = F(x_0)limx→x0+​​F(x)=F(x0​) for all x0x_0x0​.

In probability, ∀x\forall x∀x, F(x)=P(X≤x)F(x) = P(X\leq x)F(x)=P(X≤x) for some random variable XXX.

For example, if the random variable XXX has the cumulative distribution function (CDF)

FX(x)={x,x∈[0,1]1,x∈(1,∞)0,otherwise,F_X(x)=\begin{cases} x, & \text{$x \in [0, 1]$}\\1, &\text{$x\in (1, \infty)$}\\0, & \text{otherwise}\end{cases}, FX​(x)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​x,1,0,​x∈[0,1]x∈(1,∞)otherwise​,

we say the random variable XXX is uniformly distributed in [0,1][0, 1][0,1].

We can see this link as reference[^3].

Probability Density Function

The probability density function can be seen as the counterpart of pmf. For the continuous random variable XXX, its CDF FX(x)F_X(x)FX​(x) is not required to be differentiable. But if so, we can compute the derivative of the CDF FX(x)F_X(x)FX​(x): dFX(x)dx=fX(x)\frac{\mathrm{d}F_X(x)}{\mathrm{d}x} = f_X(x)dxdFX​(x)​=fX​(x).

Definition: We call the function fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x) is the probability density function with respect to the continuous random variable XXX if

FX(x)=∫−∞xfX(t)dtF_X(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{x}f_X(t)\mathrm{d}t FX​(x)=∫−∞x​fX​(t)dt

for all xxx, where FX(x)F_X(x)FX​(x) is the probability cumulative function of the random variable XXX.

For example, the random variable XXX uniformly distributed in [0,1][0, 1][0,1] has the probability density function

fX(x)={1,x∈[0,1]0,otherwise. f_X(x)=\begin{cases} 1, & \text{$x \in [0, 1]$}\\0, & \text{otherwise}\end{cases}. fX​(x)={1,0,​x∈[0,1]otherwise​.

Thus the probability of event AAA can be written as ∫x∈AfX(x)dx\int_{x\in A}f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x∫x∈A​fX​(x)dx. PS: NOT\color{red}{NOT}NOT all random variables have the probability density function.

Definition: If the pdf fXf_XfX​ is positive in the set S\mathbf{S}S, we call the set S\mathbf{S}S is the support set or support of the distribution.

One common probability - normal or Gaussian distribution\color{teal}{\text{normal or Gaussian distribution}}normal or Gaussian distribution - is often given in the pdf:

f(x∣σ2,μ)=12πσ2e−(x−μ)22σ2,f(x|\sigma^2, \mu)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}e^{-\frac{(x-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}, f(x∣σ2,μ)=2πσ2​1​e−2σ2(x−μ)2​,

where σ2\sigma^2σ2 is given positive and finite, μ\muμ is given and finite. And its support is (−∞,∞)(-\infty,\infty)(−∞,∞).

Power-law Distributions

The density function of a power law distribution is in the form of

fX(x)=x−α,x∈[1,∞)f_X(x)= x^{-\alpha}, x\in [1,\infty) fX​(x)=x−α,x∈[1,∞)

where α\alphaα is real. It is also called Pareto-type distribution.

The power law can be used to describe a phenomenon where a small number of items is clustered at the top of a distribution (or at the bottom), taking up 95% of the resources. In other words, it implies a small amount of occurrences is common, while larger occurrences are rare.

Link between discrete and continuous distributions

This is the link between discrete and continuous distributions in Wikipedia.

It is possible to represent certain discrete random variables as well as random variables involving both a continuous and a discrete part with a generalized probability density function, by using the Dirac delta function. For example, let us consider a binary discrete random variable having the Rademacher distribution — that is, taking −1 or 1 for values, with probability ½ each. The density of probability associated with this variable is

f(t)=12(δ(t+1)+δ(t−1)).f(t)=\frac{1}{2} (\delta (t+1) + \delta(t-1)). f(t)=21​(δ(t+1)+δ(t−1)).

More generally, if a discrete variable can take n different values among real numbers, then the associated probability density function is:

f(t)=∑i=1npi δ(t−xi)f(t)=\sum _{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\,\delta(t-{x}_{i}) f(t)=i=1∑n​pi​δ(t−xi​)

where x1,⋯ ,xnx_1, \cdots, x_nx1​,⋯,xn​ are the discrete values accessible to the variable and p1,⋯ ,pnp_1,\cdots, p_np1​,⋯,pn​ are the probabilities associated with these values.

This substantially unifies the treatment of discrete and continuous probability distributions. For instance, the above expression allows for determining statistical characteristics of such a discrete variable (such as its mean, its variance and its kurtosis), starting from the formulas given for a continuous distribution of the probability.

Bivariate Distribution

The cumulative probability function and probability density function are really functions with some required properties. We wonder the bivariate functions in probability theory.

Definition: The joint distribution function F:R2→[0,1]F:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow [0,1]F:R2→[0,1], where XXX and YYY are discrete variables, is given by

F(X,Y)(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y).F_{(X,Y)}(x,y)=P(X\leq x, Y\leq y). F(X,Y)​(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y).

Their joint mass function f:R2→[0,1]f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow [0,1]f:R2→[0,1] is given by

f(X,Y)(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y).f_{(X,Y)}(x,y)=P(X=x, Y=y). f(X,Y)​(x,y)=P(X=x,Y=y).

Definition: The joint distribution function F(X,Y):R2→[0,1]F_{(X,Y)}:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow [0,1]F(X,Y)​:R2→[0,1], where XXX and YYY are continuous variables, is given by F(X,Y)(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y)F_{(X,Y)}(x,y)=P(X\leq x, Y\leq y)F(X,Y)​(x,y)=P(X≤x,Y≤y). And their joint density > function if fX,Y(x,y)f_{X,Y}(x, y)fX,Y​(x,y) satisfies that

F(X,Y)(x,y)=∫v=−∞y∫u=−∞xf(X,Y)(u,v)dudvF_{(X,Y)}(x,y)=\int_{v=-\infty}^{y}\int_{u=-\infty}^{x}f_{(X,Y)}(u,v)\mathrm{d}u\mathrm{d}v F(X,Y)​(x,y)=∫v=−∞y​∫u=−∞x​f(X,Y)​(u,v)dudv

for each x,y∈Rx,y \in \mathbb{R}x,y∈R.

The marginal distribution

Definition: The marginal distributed of XXX and YYY are

  • FX(x)=P(X≤x)=F(X,Y)(x,∞)andFY(y)=P(X≤x)=F(X,Y)(∞,y)F_X(x)=P(X\leq x)=F_{(X,Y)}(x,\infty)\quad\text{and}\quad F_Y(y)=P(X\leq x)=F_{(X,Y)} (\infty, y) FX​(x)=P(X≤x)=F(X,Y)​(x,∞)andFY​(y)=P(X≤x)=F(X,Y)​(∞,y)

for discrete random variables;

  • FX(x)=∫−∞x(∫Rf(X,Y)(u,y)dy)duandFY(y)=∫−∞y(∫Rf(X,Y)(x,v)dv)dxF_X(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{x}(\int_{\mathbb{R}}f_{(X,Y)}(u, y)\mathrm{d}y)\mathrm{d}u \quad\text{and}\quad F_Y(y)=\int_{-\infty}^{y}(\int_{\mathbb{R}}f_{(X,Y)}(x,v)\mathrm{d}v)\mathrm{d}x FX​(x)=∫−∞x​(∫R​f(X,Y)​(u,y)dy)duandFY​(y)=∫−∞y​(∫R​f(X,Y)​(x,v)dv)dx

for continuous random variables and the marginal probability density function is

fX(x)=∫Rf(X,Y)(x,y)dy,fY(y)=∫Rf(X,Y)(x,y)dx.f_X(x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}f_{(X,Y)}(x, y)\mathrm{d}y,\quad f_Y(y)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}f_{(X,Y)}(x, y)\mathrm{d}x. fX​(x)=∫R​f(X,Y)​(x,y)dy,fY​(y)=∫R​f(X,Y)​(x,y)dx.

Definition: Two random variables X\color{maroon}{X}X and Y\color{olive}{Y}Y are called as identically distributed if P(x∈A)=P(y∈A)P(x\in A)=P(y\in A)P(x∈A)=P(y∈A) for any A⊂RA \subset \mathbb{R}A⊂R.

Representation of Random Variable

The random variable is nearly no sense without its probability distribution. We can choose the CDF or pdf to depict the probability, which depends on the case.

We know that a function of random variable is also a random variable. For example, supposing that X\color{teal}{X}X is a random variable, the function g(X)=eX\color{teal}{g(X)= e^{X}}g(X)=eX is a random variable as well as g(X)=ln⁡(X)\color{teal}{g(X)=\ln(X)}g(X)=ln(X).

The function of random variable must have its distribution\color{teal}{\text{The function of random variable must have its distribution}}The function of random variable must have its distribution. We can take it to generate more distributions.

Theorem Suppose that XXX is with the cumulative distribution function CDF\color{red}{\text{CDF}}CDF FX(x)F_X(x)FX​(x) and Y=FX(X)Y=F_X(X)Y=FX​(X), then YYY is uniformly\color{teal}{uniformly}uniformly distributed in the interval [0,1][0, 1][0,1].

Let XXX and YYY be two different random variables, Z=X+YZ= X+YZ=X+Y or Z=X⋅YZ = X\cdot YZ=X⋅Y are typical functions of random variables, especially XXX is discrete while YYY is continuous. More on the Wikipedia page random variable

Mixture Representation

Let P1,P2,⋯ ,PnP_1,P_2,\cdots, P_nP1​,P2​,⋯,Pn​ be probability distribution and ∑i=1nλi=1,λi>0∀i∈{1,2,⋯ ,n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_i=1,\lambda_i > 0 \quad \forall i\in\{1,2,\cdots,n\}∑i=1n​λi​=1,λi​>0∀i∈{1,2,⋯,n}, we can get

P=∑i=1nλiPiP=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_iP_i P=i=1∑n​λi​Pi​

is also a probability distribution. If XXX is distributed in PPP, i.e.X∼PX\sim PX∼P, its probability is computed as

P(X=x)=∑i=1nλiPi(X=x)P(X=x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_iP_i(X=x) P(X=x)=i=1∑n​λi​Pi​(X=x)

for discrete random variable or

P(X≤x)=∑i=1nλiPi(X≤x)P(X\leq x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_iP_i(X\leq x) P(X≤x)=i=1∑n​λi​Pi​(X≤x)

for continuous random variable.

Definition: A random variable XXX is said to have a mixture distribution if the distribution of XXX depends on a quantity that also has a distribution.

Sometimes, it is quite difficult if we directly generate a random vector X∼fX(x)X\sim f_X(x)X∼fX​(x), but the augmented vector (X,Z)⊤∼f(X,Z)(x,z)(X, Z) ^⊤\sim f_{(X,Z)}(x, z)(X,Z)⊤∼f(X,Z)​(x,z) is relatively easy to generate such as Box-Muller algorithm. And we can represent fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x) as the marginal probability distribution of f(X,Y)(x,y)f_{(X,Y)}(x,y)f(X,Y)​(x,y) in integral form

∫Rf(X,Z)(x,z)dz.\int_{\mathbb{R}}f_{(X,Z)}(x,z) \mathrm{d}z. ∫R​f(X,Z)​(x,z)dz.

It is Khintchine’s (1938) theorem that shows how to mix the distributions.

Bayes' Theorem

Bayes theorem is the foundation of Bayesian statistics in honor of the statistician Thomas Bayes [^4].

Conditional Probability

If the set AAA is the subset of BBB, i.e. A⊂BA\subset BA⊂B, we know that if x∈Ax\in Ax∈A, x∈Bx\in Bx∈B. We can say if AAA happened, the event BBB must have happened. However, if BBB happened, what is probability when AAA happened? It should be larger than the probability of AAA when BBB did not happened and it is also larger than the probability of AAA when the events including BBB happened. We know that A⋂B=AA\bigcap B=AA⋂B=A when AAA is the subset of BBB.

Definition: Supposing A,B∈ΩA, B\in \OmegaA,B∈Ω and P(B)>0P(B) > 0P(B)>0, the conditional probability of AAA given BBB(denoted as P(A∣B))P(A|B))P(A∣B)) is

P(A∣B)=P(A⋂B)P(B).P(A|B)=\frac{P(A\bigcap B)}{P(B)}. P(A∣B)=P(B)P(A⋂B)​.

The vertical bar ∣|∣ means that the right one is given or known and is parameter rather than variable.

Here is a visual explanation.

Definition: If P(A⋂B)=P(A)P(B)P(A\bigcap B)= P(A)P(B)P(A⋂B)=P(A)P(B), we call the event AAA and BBB are statistically independent.

From the definition of conditional probability, it is obvious that:

  • P(B)=P(A⋂B)P(A∣B)P(B)=\frac{P(A\bigcap B)}{P(A|B)}P(B)=P(A∣B)P(A⋂B)​
  • P(A⋂B)=P(A∣B)P(B)P(A\bigcap B)=P(A|B)P(B)P(A⋂B)=P(A∣B)P(B);
  • P(A⋂B)=P(B∣A)P(A)P(A\bigcap B)=P(B|A)P(A)P(A⋂B)=P(B∣A)P(A).

Thus

  • P(A∣B)P(B)=P(B∣A)P(A)P(A|B)P(B)=P(B|A)P(A)P(A∣B)P(B)=P(B∣A)P(A),
  • P(A∣B)=P(B∣A)P(A)P(B)=P(B∣A)P(A)P(B)P(A|B)=\frac{P(B|A)P(A)}{P(B)}=P(B|A) \frac{P(A)}{P(B)}P(A∣B)=P(B)P(B∣A)P(A)​=P(B∣A)P(B)P(A)​,
  • P(B)=P(B∣A)P(A)P(A∣B=P(B∣A)P(A∣B)P(A)P(B)=\frac{P(B|A)P(A)}{P(A|B}=\frac{P(B|A)}{P(A|B)}P(A)P(B)=P(A∣BP(B∣A)P(A)​=P(A∣B)P(B∣A)​P(A).

Definition: The conditional distribution function of YYY given X=xX=xX=x is the function FY∣X(y∣x)F_{Y|X}(y|x)FY∣X​(y∣x) given by

FY∣X(y∣x)=∫−∞xf(X,Y)(x,v)fX(x)dv=∫−∞xf(X,Y)(x,v)dvfX(x)F_{Y|X}(y|x)=\int_{-\infty}^{x}\frac{f_{(X,Y)}(x,v)}{f_X(x)}\mathrm{d}v=\frac{\int_{-\infty}^{x}f_{(X,Y)}(x,v)\mathrm{d}v}{f_{X}(x)} FY∣X​(y∣x)=∫−∞x​fX​(x)f(X,Y)​(x,v)​dv=fX​(x)∫−∞x​f(X,Y)​(x,v)dv​

for the support of fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x) and the conditional probability density function of FY∣XF_{Y|X}FY∣X​, written fY∣X(y∣x)f_{Y|X}(y|x)fY∣X​(y∣x), is given by

fY∣X(y∣x)=f(X,Y)(x,y)fX(x)f_{Y|X}(y|x)=\frac{f_{(X,Y)}(x,y)}{f_X(x)} fY∣X​(y∣x)=fX​(x)f(X,Y)​(x,y)​

for any xxx such that fX(x)>0f_X(x)>0fX​(x)>0.

Definition: If XXX and YYY are non-generate and jointly continuous random variables with density fX,Y(x,y)f_{X,Y}(x, y)fX,Y​(x,y) then, if BBB has positive measure,

P(X∈A∣Y∈B)=∫y∈B∫x∈AfX,Y(x,y)dxdy∫y∈B∫x∈RfX,Y(x,y)dxdy.P(X\in A|Y \in B)=\frac{\int_{y\in B}\int_{x\in \color{red}{A}}f_{X,Y}(x,y)\mathbb{d}x\mathbb{d}y}{\int_{y\in B}\int_{x\in \color{red}{\mathbb{R}}}f_{X,Y}(x,y)\mathbb{d}x\mathbb{d}y}. P(X∈A∣Y∈B)=∫y∈B​∫x∈R​fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy∫y∈B​∫x∈A​fX,Y​(x,y)dxdy​.

(Chain Rule of Probability)

P(x(1),⋯ ,x(n))=P(x(1))∏i=2nP(xi∣x(1),⋯ ,x(i−1))P(x^{(1)},\cdots, x^{(n)})=P(x^{(1)})\prod_{i=2}^{n}P(x^{i}|x^{(1),\cdots, x^{(i-1)}}) P(x(1),⋯,x(n))=P(x(1))i=2∏n​P(xi∣x(1),⋯,x(i−1))

More content are in wikipedia.

Definition: The event AAA and BBB are conditionally independent given CCC if and only if

P(A⋂B∣C)=P(A∣C)P(B∣C).P(A\bigcap B|C)=P(A|C)P(B|C). P(A⋂B∣C)=P(A∣C)P(B∣C).

Total Probability Theorem

This is the total probability theorem in Wikipedia.

(Total Probability Theorem) Supposing the events A1,A2,⋯A_1, A_2, \cdotsA1​,A2​,⋯ are disjoint in the sample space Ω\OmegaΩ and ⋃i=1∞Ai=Ω\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i = \Omega⋃i=1∞​Ai​=Ω, BBB is any subset of Ω\OmegaΩ, we have

P(B)=∑i=1∞P(B⋂Ai)=∑i=1∞P(B∣Ai)P(Ai).P(B)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(B\bigcap A_i)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(B|A_i)P(A_i). P(B)=i=1∑∞​P(B⋂Ai​)=i=1∑∞​P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​).

  • For the discrete random variable, the total probability theorem tells that any event can be decomposed to the basic event in the event space.
  • For the continuous random variable, this theorems means that ∫BfX(x)dx=∑i=1∞∫B⋂AifX(x)dx.\int_{\mathbb{B}}f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\int_{\mathbb{B}\bigcap\mathbb{A_i}}f_X(x)\mathbb{d}x.∫B​fX​(x)dx=∑i=1∞​∫B⋂Ai​​fX​(x)dx.

Bayes' Theorem

(Bayes' Theorem) Supposing the events A1,A2,⋯A_1, A_2, \cdotsA1​,A2​,⋯ are disjoint in the sample space Ω\OmegaΩ and ⋃i=1∞Ai=Ω\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i = \Omega⋃i=1∞​Ai​=Ω, BBB is any subset of Ω\OmegaΩ, we have

P(Ai∣B)=P(B∣Ai)P(Ai)∑i=1∞P(B∣Ai)P(Ai)=P(B∣Ai)P(Ai)P(B).P(A_i|B)=\frac{P(B|A_i)P(A_i)}{\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(B|A_i)P(A_i)}=\frac{P(B|A_i)P(A_i)}{P(B)}. P(Ai​∣B)=∑i=1∞​P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​)P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​)​=P(B)P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​)​.

  • The probability P(Ai)P(A_i)P(Ai​) is called prior probability of event AiA_iAi​ and the conditional probability P(Ai∣B)P(A_i|B)P(Ai​∣B) is called posterior probability of the event AiA_iAi​ in Bayesian statistics.
  • For any AiA_iAi​, P(Ai∣B)∝ P(B∣Ai)P(Ai)P(A_i|B)\propto\, P(B|A_i)P(A_i)P(Ai​∣B)∝P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​) and P(B)P(B)P(B) is the normalization constant as the sum of P(B∣Ai)P(Ai)P(B|A_i)P(A_i)P(B∣Ai​)P(Ai​).
Thomas Bayes, 1702-1761

Inverse Bayes' Formula

The joint pdf of the random variables XXX and YYY can be expressed as

f(x,y)(x,y)=fX∣Y(x∣y)fY(y)=fY∣X(y∣x)fX(x).f_{(x,y)}(x,y)=f_{X|Y}(x|y)f_{Y}(y)=f_{Y|X}(y|x)f_{X}(x). f(x,y)​(x,y)=fX∣Y​(x∣y)fY​(y)=fY∣X​(y∣x)fX​(x).

in some proper conditions. Thus we get by division

fY(y)=fY∣X(y∣x)fX(x)fX∣Y(x∣y).(1)f_{Y}(y)=\frac{f_{Y|X}(y|x)f_{X}(x)}{f_{X|Y}(x|y)} \tag 1. fY​(y)=fX∣Y​(x∣y)fY∣X​(y∣x)fX​(x)​.(1)

Integrating this identity with respect to yyy on support of fY(y)f_{Y}(y)fY​(y), we immediately have the point-wise formula as shown below

fX(x)={∫fX∣Y(x∣y)≠0fY∣X(y∣x)fX∣Y(x∣y)dy}−1.(2)f_{X}(x)=\{\int_{f_{X|Y}(x|y)\neq {0}}\frac{f_{Y|X}(y|x)}{f_{X|Y}(x|y)}\mathbb{d}y\}^{-1} \tag 2. fX​(x)={∫fX∣Y​(x∣y)​=0​fX∣Y​(x∣y)fY∣X​(y∣x)​dy}−1.(2)

Now substitute (2) into (1), we obtain the dual form of IBF for fY(y)f_Y(y)fY​(y) and hence by symmetry we obtain the function-wise formula of fY(y)f_Y(y)fY​(y) at y0y_0y0​ as shown in (3), or the sampling formula in (4) when the normalizing constant is omitted.

\begin{align} f_{X}(x) &=\{\int_{f_{Y|X}(y|X)\neq {0}}\frac{f_{X|Y}(x|y_0)}{f_{Y|X}(y_0|x)}\mathbb{d}x\}^{-1}\frac{f_{X|Y}(x|y_0)}{f_{Y|X}(y_0|x)} \tag 3 \\ &\propto \frac{f_{X|Y}(x|y_0)}{f_{Y|X}(y_0|x)} \tag 4 \end{align}

What determines a distribution?

The cumulative density function (CDF) or probability density function(pdf) is roughly equal to random variable, i.e. one random variable is always attached with CDF or pdf. However, what we observed is not the variable itself but its realization or sample.

  • In theory, what properties do some CDFs or pdfs hold? For example, are they all integrable?
  • In practice, the basic question is how to determine the CDF or pdf if we only observed some samples?

Expectation, Variance and Entropy

Expectation and variance are two important factors that characterize the random variable.

The expectation of a discrete random variable is defined as the weighted sum.

Definition: For a discrete random variable XXX, of which the range is x1,⋯ ,x∞{x_1,\cdots, x_{\infty}}x1​,⋯,x∞​, its (mathematical) expectation E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X) is defined as E(X)=∑i=1∞xiP(X=xi)\mathbb{E}(X)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}x_i P(X=x_i)E(X)=∑i=1∞​xi​P(X=xi​).

The expectation of a discrete random variable is a weighted sum. Average is one special expectation with equiprob, i.e. P(X=x1)=P(X=x2)=⋯=P(X=xi)=⋯∀iP(X=x_1)=P(X=x_2) = \cdots = P(X = x_i) = \cdots \forall iP(X=x1​)=P(X=x2​)=⋯=P(X=xi​)=⋯∀i.

The expectation of a continuous random variable is defined as one special integration.

Definition: For a continuous random variable XXX with the pdf f(x)f(x)f(x), if the integration ∫−∞∞∣x∣f(x)dx\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x|f(x)\mathrm{d}x∫−∞∞​∣x∣f(x)dx exists, the value ∫−∞∞xf(x)dx\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} xf(x)\mathrm{d}x∫−∞∞​xf(x)dx is called the (mathematical) expectation of XXX, which is often denoted as E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X).

Note that NOT\color{lime}{NOT}NOT all random variables have expectation. For example, standard Cauchy distribution

fX(x)=1π(1+x2)f_X(x)=\frac{1}{\pi(1+x^2)} fX​(x)=π(1+x2)1​

is undefined.

The expectation is the center of the probability density function in many cases. What is more,

arg⁡max⁡bE(X−b)2=E(X)\arg\max_{b}\mathbb{E}(X-b)^2=\mathbb{E}(X) argbmax​E(X−b)2=E(X)

which implies that E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X) is the most likeliest to appear in expectation.

Definition: Now suppose that X is a random vector X=(X1,⋯ ,Xd)X = (X_1, \cdots, X_d )X=(X1​,⋯,Xd​), where XjX_jXj​, j=1,⋯ ,d,j = 1, \cdots, d,j=1,⋯,d, is real-valued. Then E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X) is simply the vector

(E(X1),⋯ ,E(Xd))(\mathbb{E}(X_1), \cdots , \mathbb{E}(X_d)) (E(X1​),⋯,E(Xd​))

where E(Xi)=∫RxifXidxi∀i∈{1,2,⋯ ,d}\mathbb{E}(X_i)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}x_if_{X_i}\mathrm{d}x_i\forall i\in\{1,2, \cdots, d\}E(Xi​)=∫R​xi​fXi​​dxi​∀i∈{1,2,⋯,d} and fXi(xi)f_{X_i}(x_i)fXi​​(xi​) is the marginal probability density function of XiX_iXi​.

Definition: If the random variable has finite expectation E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X), then the expectation of (X−E(X))2(X-\mathbb{E}(X))^2(X−E(X))2 is called the variance of XXX (denoted as Var(X)Var(X)Var(X)), i.e. ∑i=1∞(xi−E(X))2P(X=xi)\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}(x_i-\mathbb{E}(X))^2P(X=x_i)∑i=1∞​(xi​−E(X))2P(X=xi​) for discrete random variable and ∫−∞∞(x−E(X))2fX(x)dx\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}(x-\mathbb{E}(X))^2f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x∫−∞∞​(x−E(X))2fX​(x)dx for continuous random variable.

It is obvious that

Var(X)=∫R(x−E(X))2fX(x)dx=∫X(x−E(X))2fX(x)dxVar(X)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}(x-\mathbb{E}(X))^2f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x=\int_{\mathbb{X}}(x-\mathbb{E}(X))^2f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x Var(X)=∫R​(x−E(X))2fX​(x)dx=∫X​(x−E(X))2fX​(x)dx

where the set X\mathbb{X}X is the support of XXX.

Definition: In general, let XXX be a random variable with pdf fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x), the expectation of the random variable g(X)g(X)g(X) is equal to the integration ∫Rg(x)fX(x)dx\int_{\mathbb{R}}g(x)f_X(x)\mathrm{d}x∫R​g(x)fX​(x)dx if it exists.

In analysis, the expectation of a random variable is the integration of some functions.

Definition: The conditional expectation of YYY given XXX can be defined as

Ψ(X)=E(Y∣X)=∫RyfY∣X(y∣x)dy.\Psi(X)=\mathbb{E}(Y|X)=\int_{\mathbb{R}} yf_{Y|X}(y|x)\mathrm{d}y. Ψ(X)=E(Y∣X)=∫R​yfY∣X​(y∣x)dy.

It is a parameter-dependent integral, where the parameter xxx can be considered as fixed constant. See the content in Calculus II.

Tower rule Let XXX be random variable on a sample space Ω\OmegaΩ, let the events A1,A2,⋯A_1, A_2, \cdotsA1​,A2​,⋯ are disjoint in the sample space Ω\OmegaΩ and ⋃i=1∞Ai=Ω\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}A_i = \Omega⋃i=1∞​Ai​=Ω, BBB is any subset of Ω\OmegaΩ, E(X)=∑i=1∞E(X∣Ai)P(Ai)\mathbb{E}(X)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}\mathbb{E}(X|A_i)P(A_i)E(X)=∑i=1∞​E(X∣Ai​)P(Ai​). In general, the conditional expectation Ψ(X)=E(Y∣X)\Psi(X)=\mathbb{E}(Y|X)Ψ(X)=E(Y∣X) satisfies E(Ψ(X))=E(Y).\mathbb{E}(\Psi(X))=\mathbb{E}(Y).E(Ψ(X))=E(Y).

The probability of an event can be expressed as the expectation, i.e.

Probability as Integration
P(x∈A)=∫RIAfX(x)dxP(x\in A)= \int_{\mathbb{R}}\mathbb{I}_{A}f_X(x)\mathbb{d}xP(x∈A)=∫R​IA​fX​(x)dx

where

IA={1,if x∈A0,otherwise.\mathbb{I}_{A}=\begin{cases} 1, & \text{if $x\in A$}\\ 0, & \text{otherwise}\end{cases}. IA​={1,0,​if x∈Aotherwise​.

It is called as the indictor function of AAA.

Definition: The Shannon entropy is defined as

  • H=−∑i=1∞P(X=xi)ln⁡P(X=xi)H=-\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}P(X=x_i){\ln}P(X=x_i) H=−i=1∑∞​P(X=xi​)lnP(X=xi​)

for the discrete random variable XXX with the range {x1,⋯ ,xn}\{x_1,\cdots, x_n\}{x1​,⋯,xn​} with the convention P(X=x)=0P(X=x)=0P(X=x)=0 that P(X=x)ln⁡1P(X=x)=0P(X=x){\ln}{\frac{1}{P(X=x)}}=0P(X=x)lnP(X=x)1​=0 and

  • H=∫Xln⁡(1fX(x))fX(x)dxH=\int_{\mathbb{X}}{\ln}(\frac{1}{f_X(x)})f_X(x)\mathbb{d}x H=∫X​ln(fX​(x)1​)fX​(x)dx

for the continuous random variable XXX with the support X\mathbb{X}X.

The Shannon entropy is often related to finite\color{lime}{finite}finite state discrete random variable, i.e. n<∞\color{teal}{n< \infty}n<∞ and the value of random variable is not involved in its entropy.

Claude Elwood Shannon, 1916-2001

Moment and Moment Generating Function

In calculus, we know that some proper functions can be extended as a Taylor series in a interval.

Moment is a specific quantitative measure of the shape of a function.

Definition: The nnn-th moment of a real-valued continuous function fX(x)f_X(x)fX​(x) of a real variable about a value ccc is

μn=∫x∈R(x−c)nfX(x)dx.\mu_{n} =\int_{x\in\mathbb{R}}(x-c)^n f_X(x)\mathbb{d}x. μn​=∫x∈R​(x−c)nfX​(x)dx.

And the constant ccc always take the expectation E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X) or 000.

Definition: Moment generating function of a random variable XXX is the expectation of the random variable of etXe^{tX}etX, i.e.

Moment generating function
MX(t)=∫RetxfX(x)dxM_X(t)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}e^{tx}f_X(x)\mathbb{d}xMX​(t)=∫R​etxfX​(x)dx for continuous random variable
MX(t)=∑i=1∞etxiP(x=xi)M_{X}(t)=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}e^{tx_{i}}P(x=x_i)MX​(t)=∑i=1∞​etxi​P(x=xi​) for discrete random variable

It is Laplace transformation applied to probability density function. And it is also related with cumulants.

Pierre-Simon Laplace French 1749-1827

Sampling from Discrete Distribution

(Inverse transform technique) Let FFF be a probability cumulative function of a random variable taking non-negative integer values, and let UUU be uniformly distributed on interval [0,1][0, 1][0,1]. The random variable given by X=kX=kX=k if and only if F(k−1)<U<F(k)F(k-1)<U<F(k)F(k−1)<U<F(k) has the distribution function FFF.

Sampling from Categorical Distribution

The categorical distribution (also called a generalized Bernoulli distribution, multinoulli distribution) is a discrete probability distribution that describes the possible results of a random variable that can take on one of K possible categories, with the probability of each category separately specified.

The category can be represented as one-hot vector, i.e. the vector (1,0,⋯ ,0)(1,0,\cdots, 0)(1,0,⋯,0) is referred as the first category and the others are as similar as it. This representation is of some advantages:

  1. Each category is identified by its position and equal to each other in norm;
  2. The one-hot vectors can not be compared as the real number in value;
  3. The probability mass function of the K categories distribution can be written in a compact form - P(X)=[p1,p2,⋯ ,pK]⋅XTP(\mathrm{X})=[p_1,p_2, \cdots, p_K]\cdot \mathrm{X}^TP(X)=[p1​,p2​,⋯,pK​]⋅XT, where
    • The probability pi≥0,∀i∈[1,⋯ ,K]p_i \geq 0, \forall i\in [1,\cdots, K]pi​≥0,∀i∈[1,⋯,K] and ∑i=1Kpi=1\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_i=1∑i=1K​pi​=1;
    • The random variable X\mathrm{X}X is one-hot vector and XT\mathrm{X}^TXT is the transpose of XXX.

Sampling it by inverse transform sampling:

  1. Pick a uniformly distributed number between 0 and 1.
  2. Locate the greatest number in the CDF whose value is less than or equal to the number just chosen., i.e. F−1(u)=inf{x:F(x)≤u}F^{-1}(u)=inf\{x: F(x) \leq u\}F−1(u)=inf{x:F(x)≤u}.
  3. Return the category corresponding to this CDF value. See more on Categorical distribution.

The categorical variable cannot be ordered, how to compute the CDF?\color{olive}{\text{The categorical variable cannot be ordered, how to compute the CDF?}}The categorical variable cannot be ordered, how to compute the CDF?

Sampling from Continuous Distribution

Direct Methods

(Inverse transform technique) Let FFF be a probability cumulative function of a continuous random variable, and let UUU be uniformly distributed on interval [0,1][0, 1][0,1]. The random variable X=F−1(U)X=F^{-1}(U)X=F−1(U) has the distribution function FFF.

Khintchine’s (1938) theorem: Suppose the random variable XXX with density given by

fX(x)=∫x∞z−1fZ(z)dz(0)f_{X}(x)=\int_{x}^{\infty}z^{-1}f_Z(z)\mathrm{d}z\tag 0 fX​(x)=∫x∞​z−1fZ​(z)dz(0)

or This mixture can be represented equivalently by

\begin{align} Z &\sim f_Z(z), z > 0 &\text{and} \tag 1\\ X|(Z=z) & \sim Uinf(0,z). \tag 2\\ \end{align}

Hence XZ∣(Z=z)=Xz∣(Z=z)∼ Unif(0,1)\frac{X}{Z}|(Z=z)=\frac{X}{z}|(Z=z)\sim\,Unif(0,1)ZX​∣(Z=z)=zX​∣(Z=z)∼Unif(0,1) not depending on zzz, so that

\begin{align} \frac{X}{Z}|(Z=z) =\frac{X}{z}|(Z=z) &\sim\,Unif(0,1) \\ \frac{X}{Z}\stackrel{d}=U &\sim Unif(0,1) \\ X & =ZU \tag 3 \end{align}

and UUU and ZZZ are mutually independent.

If ∇fX(x)\nabla f_X(x)∇fX​(x) exists and fX(∞)=0f_X(\infty)=0fX​(∞)=0, we can obtain the following equation by Newton-Leibiniz's theorem

fX(x)=−∫x∇fX(z)dz(4)f_X(x)=-\int_{x}\nabla f_X(z)\mathrm{d}z \tag 4 fX​(x)=−∫x​∇fX​(z)dz(4)

and comparing (4) and (0), it is obvious: ∇fX(z)=−z−1fZ(z)\nabla f_X(z)=-z^{-1}f_Z(z)∇fX​(z)=−z−1fZ​(z).

See more information on On Khintchine's Theorem and Its Place in Random Variate Generation and Reciprocal symmetry, unimodality and Khintchine’s theorem.

Rejection sampling

The rejection sampling is to draw samples from a distribution with the help of a proposal distribution.

The algorithm (used by John von Neumann and dating back to Buffon and his needle) to obtain a sample from distribution XXX with density fff using samples from distribution YYY with density ggg is as follows:

  • Obtain a sample yyy from distribution YYY and a sample uuu from Unif(0,1)\mathrm{Unif}(0,1)Unif(0,1)(the uniform distribution over the unit interval).
  • Check whether or not u<f(y)/Mg(y)u<f(y)/Mg(y)u<f(y)/Mg(y).
    • If this holds, accept yyy as a sample drawn from fff;
    • if not, reject the value of yyy and return to the sampling step.

The algorithm will take an average of MMM iterations to obtain a sample. Ziggural algorithm is an application of rejection sampling to draw samples from Gaussian distribution.

Adaptive rejection sampling

Construction of an envelope function is particularly straightforward for cases in which p(zp(zp(z is log concave, in other words when ln⁡p(z)\ln p(z)lnp(z) has derivatives that are nonincreasing functions of z{z}z. The function ln⁡p(z)\ln p(z)lnp(z) and its gradient are evaluated at some initial set of grid points, and the intersections of the resulting tangent lines are used to construct the envelope function. Next a sample value is drawn from the envelope distribution. This is straightforward because the log of the envelope distribution is a succession of linear functions, and hence the envelope distribution itself comprises a piecewise exponential distribution of the form

q(z)=kiλiexp⁡(−λi(z−zi−1),zi−1<z≤zi.q(z) = k_i \lambda_i \exp(-{\lambda}_i (z-z_{i-1}), z_{i-1}< z \leq z_{i}. q(z)=ki​λi​exp(−λi​(z−zi−1​),zi−1​<z≤zi​.

John von Neumann, 1903-1957

Sampling-importance-resampling

It is also called SIR method in short. As name shown, it consists of two steps: sampling and importance sampling. The SIR method generates an approximate i.i.d. sample of size mmm from the target density f(x),x∈X⊂Rn.f(x),x\in \mathbb{X}\subset\mathbb{R}^n.f(x),x∈X⊂Rn..

The SIR without replacement is as following:

  1. Draw X(1),X(2),⋯ ,X(J)X^{(1)},X^{(2)},\cdots,X^{(J)}X(1),X(2),⋯,X(J) independently from the proposal density g(⋅)g(\cdot)g(⋅).
  2. Select a subset {X(ki)}i=1m\{X^{(k_i)}\}_{i=1}^{m}{X(ki​)}i=1m​ from {X(i)}i=1J\{X^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{J}{X(i)}i=1J​ via resampling without replacement from the discrete distribution {ωi}i=1J\{\omega_i\}_{i=1}^{J}{ωi​}i=1J​
    • where wi=f(X(i))g(X(i))w_i=\frac{f(X^{(i)})}{g(X^{(i)})}wi​=g(X(i))f(X(i))​ and ωi=wi∑i=1nwi\omega_i=\frac{w_i}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_i}ωi​=∑i=1n​wi​wi​​.

The Conditional Sampling Method

The conditional sampling method due to the prominent Rosenblatt transformation is particularly available when the joint distribution of a ddd vector is very difficult to generate but one marginal distribution and d−1d-1d−1 univariate conditional distributions are easy to simulate.

It is based on the chain rule of probability:

f(x)=f(xd)∏i=1d−1fk(xk∣xk+1,xk+2,⋯ ,xd)f(x)=f(x_d)\prod_{i=1}^{d-1}f_{k}( x_k |x_{k+1}, x_{k+2},\cdots, x_d ) f(x)=f(xd​)i=1∏d−1​fk​(xk​∣xk+1​,xk+2​,⋯,xd​)

where x=(x1,x2,⋯ ,xd)x=(x_1,x_2,\cdots, x_d)x=(x1​,x2​,⋯,xd​) and f(x)f(x)f(x) is the probability density function.

To generate XXX from f(x)f(x)f(x), we only need to generate xdx_dxd​ from the marginal density fd(xd)f_d(x_d)fd​(xd​), then to generate xkx_kxk​ sequentially from the conditional density fk(xk∣xk+1,xk+2,⋯ ,xd)f_k(x_k|x_{k+1}, x_{k+2}, \cdots, x_d)fk​(xk​∣xk+1​,xk+2​,⋯,xd​).

The Vertical Density Representation Method

Law of Large Number

The law of large number provides theoretical guarantee to estimate the expectation of distributions from the samples.

(Strong law of large numbers): Let X1,X2,…X_1,X_2,\dotsX1​,X2​,… be a sequence of independently identically distributed (i.i.d.) random variables (r.v.s) with expectation μ\muμ. Consider the sum:

XˉN=X1+X2+⋯+XN.\bar{X}_N = X_1 + X_2 + \cdots + X_N. XˉN​=X1​+X2​+⋯+XN​.

Then as N→∞N\to\inftyN→∞,

P(lim⁡N→∞XˉN=μ)=1P(\lim_{N\to\infty}\bar{X}_N=\mu)=1 P(N→∞lim​XˉN​=μ)=1

i.e.

XˉN→a.s.μ.\bar{X}_N\stackrel{a.s.}\to\mu. XˉN​→a.s.μ.

See more on Wikipedia.

Central Limit Theorem

Lindeberg–Lévy CLT. Suppose X1,X2,⋯{X_1, X_2,\cdots}X1​,X2​,⋯ is a sequence of i.i.d. random variables with E[Xi]=μE[X_i] = \muE[Xi​]=μ and Var[Xi]=σ2<∞Var[X_i] = \sigma^2 < \inftyVar[Xi​]=σ2<∞. Then as nnn approaches infinity, the random variables n(Xˉn−μ)\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n − \mu)n​(Xˉn​−μ) converge in distribution to a normal N(0,σ2)N(0,\sigma^2)N(0,σ2):

n(Xˉn−μ)→dN(0,σ2).\sqrt{n}(\bar{X}_n − \mu)\stackrel{d}\to N(0,\sigma^2). n​(Xˉn​−μ)→dN(0,σ2).

The Wikipedia page has more information. https://www.datasciencecentral.com/profiles/blogs/new-perspective-on-central-limit-theorem-and-related-stats-topics

Multivariate Normal Distribution

Definition: A random variable \calX=(X1,X2,⋯ ,Xn)T\cal{X}=(X_1,X_2,\cdots, X_n)^{T}\calX=(X1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​)T is multivariate normal if any linear combination of the random variable X1,X2,⋯ ,XnX_1,X_2,\cdots, X_nX1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​ is normally distributed, i.e.

a1X1+a2X2+⋯+anXn=a⃗T\calX∼N(μ,σ2)a_1X_1+a_2X_2+\cdots+a_nX_n=\vec{a}^T\cal{X}\sim{N(\mu,\sigma^2)} a1​X1​+a2​X2​+⋯+an​Xn​=aT\calX∼N(μ,σ2)

where a⃗=(a1,a2,⋯ ,an)T\vec{a}=(a_1,a_2,\cdots,a_n)^{T}a=(a1​,a2​,⋯,an​)T and μ<∞\mu < \inftyμ<∞, 0<σ2<∞0< \sigma^2<\infty0<σ2<∞.

If \calX\cal{X}\calX is multivariate normal, it also has a mean vector μ\muμ such that

μ=(E(X1),E(X2),⋯ ,E(Xn))\mu=(\mathbb{E}(X_1),\mathbb{E}(X_2),\cdots, \mathbb{E}(X_n)) μ=(E(X1​),E(X2​),⋯,E(Xn​))

where E(X)\mathbb{E}(X)E(X) is the expectation(or mean) of the random variable. The random vector \calX\cal{X}\calX also has a covariance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ satisfying

Σij=Cov(Xi,Xj)\Sigma_{ij}=Cov(X_i,X_j) Σij​=Cov(Xi​,Xj​)

where Cov(Xi,Xj)=E[(Xi−E(Xi))(Xj−E(Xj))]Cov(X_i,X_j)=\mathbb{E}[(X_i-\mathbb{E}(X_i))(X_j-\mathbb{E}(X_j))]Cov(Xi​,Xj​)=E[(Xi​−E(Xi​))(Xj​−E(Xj​))] is the covariance of the random variables XiX_iXi​ and XjX_jXj​.

The probability density function of a multivariate normal random vector \calX\cal{X}\calX is given by

p(x⃗∣μ,Σ)=1(2π)n2∣Σ∣12exp(−(x⃗−μ)TΣ−1(x⃗−μ))p(\vec{x}|\mu,\Sigma)=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{\frac{n}{2}}|\Sigma|^{\frac{1}{2}}}exp(-(\vec{x}-\mu)^{T}\Sigma^{-1}(\vec{x}-\mu)) p(x∣μ,Σ)=(2π)2n​∣Σ∣21​1​exp(−(x−μ)TΣ−1(x−μ))

where exp(x)=exexp(x)=e^{x}exp(x)=ex and x⃗\vec{x}x is a realization of \calX\cal{X}\calX, ∣⋅∣|\cdot|∣⋅∣ is determinant. Because \calX\cal{X}\calX is completely defined by μ\muμ and Σ\SigmaΣ, it is convenient to write

\calX∼N(μ,Σ).\cal{X}\sim N(\mu,\Sigma). \calX∼N(μ,Σ).

Stochastic processes focus on the independent random variables. For more information see the Wikipedia page.

Poisson Process

Poisson process is named after the statistician Siméon Denis Poisson.

Definition:The homogeneous Poisson point process, when considered on the positive half-line, can be defined as a counting process, a type of stochastic process, which can be denoted as {N(t),t≥0}\{N(t),t\geq 0\}{N(t),t≥0}. A counting process represents the total number of occurrences or events that have happened up to and including time ttt. A counting process is a Poisson counting process with rate λ>0\lambda >0λ>0 if it has the following three properties:

  • N(0)=0N(0)=0N(0)=0;
  • has independent increments, i.e. N(t)−N(t−τ)N(t)-N(t-\tau)N(t)−N(t−τ) and N(t+τ)−N(t)N(t+\tau)-N(t)N(t+τ)−N(t) are independent for 0≤τ≤t0\leq\tau\leq{t}0≤τ≤t; and
  • the number of events (or points) in any interval of length ttt is a Poisson random variable with parameter (or mean) λt\lambda tλt.
Siméon Denis Poisson
Poisson distribution

It is a discrete distribution with the pmf:

P(X=k)=e−λλkk!,k∈{0,1,⋯ },P(X=k)=e^{-\lambda}\frac{\lambda^k}{k!}, k\in\{0,1,\cdots\}, P(X=k)=e−λk!λk​,k∈{0,1,⋯},

where k!k!k! is the factorial of kkk, i.e. k!=k×(k−1)×(k−2)⋯×2×1k!=k\times{(k-1)}\times{(k-2)}\cdots\times{2}\times{1}k!=k×(k−1)×(k−2)⋯×2×1. See more in Wikipedia page.

Markov Chain

Markov chain is a simple stochastic process in honor of Andrey (Andrei) Andreyevich Marko.

Definition: The process XXX is a Markov chain if it satisfies the Markov condition:

P(Xn=xn∣X1=x1,⋯ ,Xn−1=xn−1)=P(Xn=xn∣Xn−1=xn−1)P(X_{n}=x_{n}|X_{1}=x_{1},\cdots,X_{n-1}=x_{n-1})=P(X_{n}=x_{n}|X_{n-1}=x_{n-1}) P(Xn​=xn​∣X1​=x1​,⋯,Xn−1​=xn−1​)=P(Xn​=xn​∣Xn−1​=xn−1​)

for all n≥1n\geq 1n≥1.

People introduced to Markov chains through a typical course on stochastic processes have usually only seen examples where the state space is finite or countable. If the state space is finite, written {x1,⋯ ,xn}\{x_1,\cdots,x_n\}{x1​,⋯,xn​}, then the initial distribution can be associated with a vector λ=(λ1,⋯ ,λn)\lambda =(\lambda_1,\cdots, \lambda_n)λ=(λ1​,⋯,λn​) defined by

P(X=xi)=λii=1,⋯ ,n,P(X=x_i)=\lambda_i\quad i=1,\cdots, n, P(X=xi​)=λi​i=1,⋯,n,

and the transition probabilities can be associated with a matrix PPP having elements pijp_{i j}pij​ defined by

P(Xn+1=xi∣Xn=xj)=piji=1,⋯ ,n,and j=1,⋯ ,n.P(X_{n+1}=x_i|X_n=x_j)=p_{i j}\quad i=1,\cdots, n,\text{and}\, j=1,\cdots,n. P(Xn+1​=xi​∣Xn​=xj​)=pij​i=1,⋯,n,andj=1,⋯,n.

When the state space is countably infinite, we can think of an infinite vector and matrix. But most Markov chains of interest in MCMC have uncountable state space, and then we cannot think of the initial distribution as a vector or the transition probability distribution as a matrix. We must think of them as an unconditional probability distribution and a conditional probability distribution.

Stationarity

A stochastic process is stationary if for every positive integer kkk the distribution of the k-tuple

(Xn+1,Xn+2,⋯ ,Xn+k)(X_{n+1},X_{n+2}, \cdots , X_{n+k}) (Xn+1​,Xn+2​,⋯,Xn+k​)

does not depend on nnn. A Markov chain is stationary if it is a stationary stochastic process. In a Markov chain, the conditional distribution of (Xn+2,⋯ ,Xn+k)(X_{n+2}, \cdots , X_{n+k})(Xn+2​,⋯,Xn+k​) given Xn+1X_{n+1}Xn+1​ does not depend on nnn. It follows that a Markov chain is stationary if and only if the marginal distribution of XnX_nXn​ does not depend on nnn.

An initial distribution is said to be stationary or invariant or equilibrium for some transition probability distribution if the Markov chain specified by this initial distribution and transition probability distribution is stationary. We also indicate this by saying that the transition probability distribution preserves the initial distribution.

Stationarity implies stationary transition probabilities, but not vice versa.

Reversibility

A transition probability distribution is reversible with respect to an initial distribution if, for the Markov chain X1,X2,⋯X_1, X_2, \cdotsX1​,X2​,⋯ they specify, the distribution of pairs (Xi,Xi+1)(X_i, X_{i+1})(Xi​,Xi+1​) is exchangeable.

A Markov chain is reversible if its transition probability is reversible with respect to its initial distribution. Reversibility implies stationarity, but not vice versa. A reversible Markov chain has the same laws running forward or backward in time, that is, for any iii and kkk the distributions of (Xi+1,⋯ ,Xi+k)(X_{i+1}, \cdots , X_{i+k})(Xi+1​,⋯,Xi+k​) and (Xi+k,⋯ ,Xi+1)(X_{i+k}, \cdots , X_{i+1})(Xi+k​,⋯,Xi+1​) are the same.

Andrey (Andrei) Andreyevich Markov,1856-1922

Importance sampling

Let X⃗\vec{X}X be a random vector, and we wan to compute the integration or the expectation

μ=E(f(X⃗))=∫Rf(X⃗)p(X)dX,\mu=\mathbb{E}(f(\vec{X}))=\int_{\mathbb{R}}f(\vec{X})p({X})\mathrm{d}X, μ=E(f(X))=∫R​f(X)p(X)dX,

where p(X)p({X})p(X) is the probability density function of X⃗\vec{X}X. We can rewrite the expectation

μ=∫Rf(X⃗)p(X)q(X)q(X)dX=Eq(f(X⃗)p(X)q(X)),\mu=\int_{\mathbb{R}}\frac{f(\vec{X})p(X)}{q(X)}q(X)\mathbb{d}X=\mathbb{E}_{q}(\frac{f(\vec{X})p(X)}{q(X)}), μ=∫R​q(X)f(X)p(X)​q(X)dX=Eq​(q(X)f(X)p(X)​),

where q(X)q(X)q(X) is another probability density function and q(X)=0q(X)=0q(X)=0 implies f(X⃗)p(X)=0f(\vec{X})p(X)=0f(X)p(X)=0.

The algorithm of importance sampling is as following:

  1. Generate samples X⃗1,X⃗2,⋯ ,X⃗n\vec{X}_1,\vec{X}_2,\cdots,\vec{X}_nX1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​ from the distribution q(X)q(X)q(X);
  2. Compute the estimator μ^q=1n∑i=1nf(Xi⃗)p(Xi⃗)q(Xi⃗)\hat{\mu}_{q} =\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{f(\vec{X_i})p(\vec{X_i})}{q(\vec{X_i})}μ^​q​=n1​∑i=1n​q(Xi​​)f(Xi​​)p(Xi​​)​

Statistical Estimation

It is based on the assumption that the data are independently identically distributed (IID).

Definition: Any function of sample W(X1,X2,⋯ ,Xn)W(X_1,X_2,\cdots, X_n)W(X1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​) is called a point estimator.

Note\color{red}{Note}Note: A point estimator is a random variable or statistic.

The Method of Moments Estimator

The moments method is to estimate the moments of probability distribution function via sample moments.

The nnnth sample moment is defined as

μ^n=1L∑i=1LXin.\hat{\mu}_{n}=\frac{1}{L}\sum_{i=1}^{L}X_{i}^{n}. μ^​n​=L1​i=1∑L​Xin​.

The method of moments estimator θ^L\hat{\theta}_Lθ^L​ is defined to be the value of θ\thetaθ such that

μj(θ^L)=μ^j,∀j∈{1,2,⋯ ,k}.\mu_{j}(\hat{\theta}_L)=\hat{\mu}_{j},\forall j\in\{1,2,\cdots,k\}. μj​(θ^L​)=μ^​j​,∀j∈{1,2,⋯,k}.

By solving the above system of equations for theta^\hat{theta}theta^ in the term of μ^j\hat{\mu}_{j}μ^​j​, we will obtain the method of moments estimator.

See more on Wikipedia.

Maximum Likelihood Estimation

Maximum likelihood estimation is a method to estimate the parameters of statistical independent identical distributed samples. It is based on the belief that what we observed is what is most likely to happen. Let us start with an example.

Supposing X1,X2,⋯ ,Xn∼i.i.d.N(μ,σ2)X_1,X_2,\cdots, X_n\stackrel{i.i.d.}{\sim}\mathrm{N}(\mu,\sigma^2)X1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​∼i.i.d.N(μ,σ2), we can get the joint distribution of their samples {x1,x2,⋯ ,xn}\{x_1,x_2,\cdots, x_n\}{x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​}:

L(θ∣x1,⋯ ,xn)=∏i=1n12πσ2e−(xi−μ)22σ2.L(\theta|x_1,\cdots, x_n)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}e^{-\frac{(x_i-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}. L(θ∣x1​,⋯,xn​)=i=1∏n​2πσ2​1​e−2σ2(xi​−μ)2​.

The independency of the random variables can directly infer their joint probability is the product of each probability.

We want to find the optimal parameters μ^,σ^2\hat{\mu},\hat{\sigma}^2μ^​,σ^2 of the probability density function:

arg⁡max⁡θL(θ∣x1,⋯ ,xn)=arg⁡max⁡θℓ(θ∣x1,⋯ ,xn)\arg\max_{\theta}L(\theta|x_1,\cdots, x_n)=\arg\max_{\theta}\ell(\theta|x_1,\cdots,x_n) argθmax​L(θ∣x1​,⋯,xn​)=argθmax​ℓ(θ∣x1​,⋯,xn​)

where the log-likelihood function ℓ(θ∣x1,⋯ ,xn)\ell(\theta|x_1,\cdots,x_n)ℓ(θ∣x1​,⋯,xn​) is defined as the logarithm of likelihood function, i.e.

arg⁡max⁡μ,σ2ℓ(μ,σ2∣x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)=arg⁡max⁡μ,σ2∑i=1n−(xi−μ)22σ2−nlog⁡2πσ2.\arg\max_{\mu,\sigma^2} \ell(\mu,\sigma^2|x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)=\arg\max_{\mu,\sigma^2}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{-\frac{(x_i-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}-n\log{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}}. argμ,σ2max​ℓ(μ,σ2∣x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​)=argμ,σ2max​i=1∑n​−2σ2(xi​−μ)2​−nlog2πσ2​.

Setting ∂ℓ∂μ=0\frac{\partial\ell}{\partial{\mu}}=0∂μ∂ℓ​=0 and ∂ℓ∂σ2=0\frac{\partial\ell}{\partial{\sigma^2}}=0∂σ2∂ℓ​=0, we can get μ^=xˉ=∑i=1nxin\hat\mu=\bar{x}=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_i}{n}μ^​=xˉ=n∑i=1n​xi​​ and σ^2=∑i=1n(xi−μ)2xˉ\hat\sigma^2=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_i-\mu)^2}{\bar{x}}σ^2=xˉ∑i=1n​(xi​−μ)2​ as their maximum likelihood estimation.

Definition: For each sample point XXX, let θ^(X)\hat{\theta}(X)θ^(X) be a parameter value at which L(θ∣X)L(\theta|X)L(θ∣X) attains its maximum as a function of XXX , with XXX held fixed. A maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of the parameter θ\thetaθ based on a sample XXX is θ^(X)\hat{\theta}(X)θ^(X).

One limitation of maximum likelihood estimation is that it does not work for the mixture distribution. For example, it is impossible to estimate this mixture density function

p(x,α,σ)=12σ2πexp⁡(−(x−α)22σ2)+122πexp⁡(−x22)p(x,\alpha,\sigma)=\frac{1}{2\sigma\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-\frac{(x-\alpha)^2}{2\sigma^2})+\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-\frac{x^2}{2}) p(x,α,σ)=2σ2π​1​exp(−2σ2(x−α)2​)+22π​1​exp(−2x2​)

where the parameter α,σ\alpha,\sigmaα,σ is unknown.

We can see more in the Wikipedia page.

Bayesian Estimation of Parameters

Bayesian inference is usually carried out in the following way[^7].

  1. We choose a probability density function f(θ)f(\theta)f(θ) - called the prior distribution- that express our degrees of beliefs on a parameter of interest θ\thetaθ before we see any data.
  2. We choose a statistical model f(x∣θ)f(x|\theta)f(x∣θ) that reflects our beliefs about xxx given θ\thetaθ.
  3. After observing data X1,X2,⋯ ,XnX_1, X_2,\cdots, X_nX1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​, we update our beliefs and form the posterior distribution f(θ∣X1,X2,⋯ ,Xn)f(\theta|X_1, X_2,\cdots, X_n)f(θ∣X1​,X2​,⋯,Xn​).

For example, the Bayesian version of maximum likelihood estimation will find the parameters θ\thetaθ that maximizes the posterior f(θ∣X)f(θ)f(\theta|X)f(\theta)f(θ∣X)f(θ) where f(θ∣X)f(\theta|X)f(θ∣X) is the likelihood function of samples, i.e. f(θ∣X)=L(θ∣X1,…,Xn)f(\theta|X)=L(\theta|X_1,\dots,X_n)f(θ∣X)=L(θ∣X1​,…,Xn​). The Bayesian estimator is

θ^=arg⁡max⁡θf(θ∣X)f(θ).\hat{\theta}=\arg{\max}_{\theta} f(\theta|X)f(\theta). θ^=argmaxθ​f(θ∣X)f(θ).

Confidence Interval Estimation

The pivot quantity is the core.

Definition: A 1−α1-\alpha1−α confidence interval for a parameter θ\thetaθ an interval Cn=(a,b)C_n = (a, b)Cn​=(a,b) where a=a(X1,⋯ ,Xn)a = a(X_1,\cdots,X_n)a=a(X1​,⋯,Xn​) and b=b(X1,⋯ ,Xn)b = b(X_1,\cdots,X_n)b=b(X1​,⋯,Xn​) are functions of the data {X1,⋯ ,Xn}\{X_1,\cdots,X_n\}{X1​,⋯,Xn​} such that

Pθ(θ∈Cn)≥1−θ.P_{\theta}(\theta\in C_n)\geq 1- \theta. Pθ​(θ∈Cn​)≥1−θ.

Note: CnC_nCn​ is random and θ\thetaθ is fixed! If θ\thetaθ is a vector then we use a confidence set (such a sphere or an ellipse) instead of an interval. An interpretation is this[^7].

On day 1, you collect data and construct a 95 percent confidence interval for a parameter θ1\theta_1θ1​. On day 2, you collect new data and construct a 95 per cent confidence interval for an unrelated parameter θ2\theta_2θ2​. On day 3, you collect new data and construct a 95 percent confidence interval for an unrelated parameter θ3\theta_3θ3​. You continue this way constructing confidence intervals for a sequence of unrelated parameters θ2,θ2,⋯\theta_2,\theta_2,\cdotsθ2​,θ2​,⋯. Then 95 percent your intervals will trap the true parameter value. There is no need to introduce the idea of repeating the same experiment over and over.

See the thereby links for more information:

  • The Fallacy of Placing Confidence in Confidence Intervals;
  • BS704_Confidence_Intervals;
  • Wikipedia page;
  • http://www.stat.yale.edu/Courses/1997-98/101/confint.htm

Numerical Optimization

IN A Few Useful Things to Know about Machine Learning, Pedro Domingos put up a relation: LEARNING=REPRESENTATION+EVALUATION+OPTIMIZATION.\color{aqua}{LEARNING = REPRESENTATION + EVALUATION + OPTIMIZATION}.LEARNING=REPRESENTATION+EVALUATION+OPTIMIZATION.

  • Representation as the core of the note is the general (mathematical) model that computer can handle.
  • Evaluation is criteria. An evaluation function (also called objective function, cost function or scoring function) is needed to distinguish good classifiers from bad ones.
  • Optimization is to aimed to find the parameters taht optimizes the evaluation function, i.e.

    arg⁡min⁡θf(θ)={θ∗∣f(θ∗)=min⁡f(θ)} or arg⁡max⁡θf(θ)={θ∗∣f(θ∗)=max⁡f(θ)}.\arg\min_{\theta} f(\theta)=\{\theta^*|f(\theta^*)=\min f(\theta)\}\,\text{or}\,\arg\max_{\theta}f(\theta)=\{\theta^*|f(\theta^*)=\max f(\theta)\}. argθmin​f(θ)={θ∗∣f(θ∗)=minf(θ)}orargθmax​f(θ)={θ∗∣f(θ∗)=maxf(θ)}.

The objective function to be minimized is also called cost function.

Evaluation is always attached with optimization; the evavluation which cannot be optimized is not a good evaluation in machine learning.

Gradient Descent and More

Each iteration of a line search method computes a search direction pkp^{k}pk and then decides how far to move along that direction. The iteration is given by

xk+1=xk+αkpk(Line search)x^{k+1}=x^{k}+\alpha_{k}p^{k}\tag{Line search} xk+1=xk+αk​pk(Line search)

where the positive scalar αk\alpha^{k}αk is called the step length. The success of a line search method depends on effective choices of both the direction pkp^{k}pk and the step length αk\alpha_{k}αk​.

Note\color{lime}{Note}Note: we use the notation xkx^{k}xk and αk\alpha_kαk​ to represent the kkkth iteration of the vector variables xxx and kkkth step length, respectively. Most line search algorithms require pk to be a descent direction—one for which <pk,∇fk><0\left< {p^k},\nabla f_k \right> < 0⟨pk,∇fk​⟩<0 — because this property guarantees that the function fff can be reduced along this direction, where ∇fk\nabla f_k∇fk​ is the gradient of objective function fff at the kkkth iteration point xkx_kxk​ i.e. ∇fk=∇f(xk)\nabla f_k=\nabla f(x^{k})∇fk​=∇f(xk).

Gradient descent and its variants are to find the local solution of the unconstrained optimization problem:

min⁡f(x)\min f(x) minf(x)

where x∈Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn.

Its iterative procedure is:

xk+1=xk−αk∇xf(xk)x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha_{k}\nabla_{x}f(x^k) xk+1=xk−αk​∇x​f(xk)

where xkx^{k}xk is the kkkth iterative result, αk∈{α∣f(xk+1)<f(xk)}\alpha_{k}\in\{\alpha|f(x^{k+1})< f(x^{k})\}αk​∈{α∣f(xk+1)<f(xk)} and particularly αk=arg⁡min⁡αf(xk−α∇xf(xk))\alpha_{k}=\arg\min_{\alpha}f(x^{k}-\alpha\nabla_{x}f(x^{k}))αk​=argminα​f(xk−α∇x​f(xk)).

Some variants of gradient descent methods are not line search method. For example, the heavy ball method:

xk+1=xk−αk∇xf(xk)+ρk(xk−xk−1)x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha_{k}\nabla_{x}f(x^k)+\rho_{k}(x^k-x^{k-1}) xk+1=xk−αk​∇x​f(xk)+ρk​(xk−xk−1)

where the momentum coefficient ρk∈[0,1]\rho_k\in[0,1]ρk​∈[0,1] generally and the step length αk\alpha_kαk​ cannot be determined by line search.

Nesterov accelerated gradient method:

\begin{align} x^{k}=y^{k}-\alpha^{k+1}\nabla_{x}f(y^k) \qquad &\text{Descent} \\ y^{k+1}=x^{k}+\rho^{k}(x^{k}-x^{k-1}) \qquad &\text{Momentum} \end{align}

where the momentum coefficient ρk∈[0,1]\rho_k\in[0,1]ρk​∈[0,1] generally.

Inventor of Nesterov accelerated Gradient

Mirror Gradient Method

It is often called mirror descent. It can be regarded as non-Euclidean generalization of projected gradient descent to solve some constrained optimization problems.

Projected Gradient Descent

Projected gradient descent is aimed to solve convex optimization problem with explicit constraints, i.e.

arg⁡min⁡x∈Sf(x)\arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{S}}f(x) argx∈Smin​f(x)

where S⊂Rn\mathbb{S}\subset\mathbb{R}^nS⊂Rn. It has two steps:

\begin{align} z^{k+1} = x^{k}-\alpha_k\nabla_x f(x^{k}) &\qquad \text{Gradient descent}\\ x^{k+1} = Proj_{\mathbb{S}}(z^{k+1})=\arg\min_{x\in \mathbb{S}}\|x-z^{k+1}\|^{2} &\qquad\text{Projection} \end{align}

Mirror descent

Mirror descent can be regarded as the non-Euclidean generalization via replacing the ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm or Euclidean distance in projected gradient descent by Bregman divergence.

Bregman divergence is induced by convex smooth function fff:

B(x,y)=f(x)−f(y)−<∇f(y),x−y>B(x,y)=f(x)-f(y)-\left<\nabla f(y),x-y\right> B(x,y)=f(x)−f(y)−⟨∇f(y),x−y⟩

where <⋅,⋅>\left<\cdot,\cdot\right>⟨⋅,⋅⟩ is inner product. Especially, when fff is quadratic function, the Bregman divergence induced by fff is

B(x,y)=x2−y2−<2y,x−y>=x2+y2−2xy=(x−y)2B(x,y)=x^2-y^2-\left<2y,x-y\right>=x^2+y^2-2xy=(x-y)^2 B(x,y)=x2−y2−⟨2y,x−y⟩=x2+y2−2xy=(x−y)2

i.e. the Euclidean distance. A wonderful introduction to Bregman divergence is Meet the Bregman Divergences by Mark Reid at http://mark.reid.name/blog/meet-the-bregman-divergences.html.

It is given by:

\begin{align} z^{k+1} = x^{k}-\alpha_k\nabla_x f(x^{k}) &\qquad \text{Gradient descent}\\ x^{k+1} = \arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{S}}B(x,z^{k+1}) &\qquad\text{Bregman projection} \end{align}.

One special method is called entropic mirror descent when f=exf=e^xf=ex and S\mathbb{S}S is simplex.

See more on the following link list.

  • https://blogs.princeton.edu/imabandit/2013/04/18/orf523-mirror-descent-part-iiii/

Variable Metric Methods

Newton's Method

NEWTON’S METHOD and QUASI-NEWTON METHODS are classified to variable metric methods.

It is also to find the solution of unconstrained optimization problems, i.e.

min⁡f(x)\min f(x) minf(x)

where x∈Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^{n}x∈Rn.

Newton's method is given by

xk+1=xk−αk+1H−1(xk)∇x f(xk)x^{k+1}=x^{k}-\alpha^{k+1}H^{-1}(x^{k})\nabla_{x}\,{f(x^{k})} xk+1=xk−αk+1H−1(xk)∇x​f(xk)

where H−1(xk)H^{-1}(x^{k})H−1(xk) is inverse of the Hessian matrix of the function f(x)f(x)f(x) at the point xkx^{k}xk. It is called Newton–Raphson algorithm in statistics. Especially when the log-likelihood function ℓ(θ)\ell(\theta)ℓ(θ) is well-behaved, a natural candidate for finding the MLE is the Newton–Raphson algorithm with quadratic convergence rate.

The Fisher Scoring Algorithm

In maximum likelihood estimation, the objective function is the log-likelihood function, i.e.

ℓ(θ)=∑i=1nlog⁡P(xi∣θ)\ell(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\log{P(x_i|\theta)} ℓ(θ)=i=1∑n​logP(xi​∣θ)

where P(xi∣θ)P(x_i|\theta)P(xi​∣θ) is the probability of realization Xi=xiX_i=x_iXi​=xi​ with the unknown parameter θ\thetaθ. However, when the sample random variable {Xi}i=1n\{X_i\}_{i=1}^{n}{Xi​}i=1n​ are not observed or realized, it is best to replace negative Hessian matrix (i.e. -∂2ℓ(θ)∂θ∂θT\frac{\partial^2\ell(\theta)}{\partial\theta\partial\theta^{T}}∂θ∂θT∂2ℓ(θ)​) of the likelihood function with the
observed information matrix:

J(θ)=E(-∂2ℓ(θ)∂θ∂θT)=−∫∂2ℓ(θ)∂θ∂θTf(x1,⋯ ,xn∣θ)dx1⋯dxnJ(\theta)=\mathbb{E}(\color{red}{\text{-}}\frac{\partial^2\ell(\theta)}{\partial\theta\partial\theta^{T}})=\color{red}{-}\int\frac{\partial^2\ell(\theta)}{\partial\theta\partial\theta^{T}}f(x_1, \cdots, x_n|\theta)\mathrm{d}x_1\cdots\mathrm{d}x_n J(θ)=E(-∂θ∂θT∂2ℓ(θ)​)=−∫∂θ∂θT∂2ℓ(θ)​f(x1​,⋯,xn​∣θ)dx1​⋯dxn​

where f(x1,⋯ ,xn∣θ)f(x_1, \cdots, x_n|\theta)f(x1​,⋯,xn​∣θ) is the joint probability density function of X1,⋯ ,XnX_1, \cdots, X_nX1​,⋯,Xn​ with unknown parameter θ\thetaθ.

And the Fisher scoring algorithm is given by

θk+1=θk+αkJ−1(θk)∇θℓ(θk)\theta^{k+1}=\theta^{k}+\alpha_{k}J^{-1}(\theta^{k})\nabla_{\theta} \ell(\theta^{k}) θk+1=θk+αk​J−1(θk)∇θ​ℓ(θk)

where J−1(θk)J^{-1}(\theta^{k})J−1(θk) is the inverse of observed information matrix at the point θk\theta^{k}θk.

See http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/~steffen/teaching/bs2HT9/scoring.pdf or https://wiseodd.github.io/techblog/2018/03/11/fisher-information/.

Fisher scoring algorithm is regarded as an example of Natural Gradient Descent in information geometry such as https://wiseodd.github.io/techblog/2018/03/14/natural-gradient/ and https://www.zhihu.com/question/266846405.

Quasi-Newton Methods

Quasi-Newton methods, like steepest descent, require only the gradient of the objective function to be supplied at each iterate. By measuring the changes in gradients, they construct a model of the objective function that is good enough to produce superlinear convergence. The improvement over steepest descent is dramatic, especially on difficult problems. Moreover, since second derivatives are not required, quasi-Newton methods are sometimes more efficient than Newton’s method.[^11]

In optimization, quasi-Newton methods (a special case of variable-metric methods) are algorithms for finding local maxima and minima of functions. Quasi-Newton methods are based on Newton's method to find the stationary point of a function, where the gradient is 0. In quasi-Newton methods the Hessian matrix does not need to be computed. The Hessian is updated by analyzing successive gradient vectors instead. Quasi-Newton methods are a generalization of the secant method to find the root of the first derivative for multidimensional problems. In multiple dimensions the secant equation is under-determined, and quasi-Newton methods differ in how they constrain the solution, typically by adding a simple low-rank update to the current estimate of the Hessian. One of the chief advantages of quasi-Newton methods over Newton's method is that the Hessian matrix (or, in the case of quasi-Newton methods, its approximation) BBB does not need to be inverted. The Hessian approximation BBB is chosen to satisfy

∇f(xk+1)=∇f(xk)+B(xk+1−xk),\nabla f(x^{k+1})=\nabla f(x^{k})+B(x^{k+1}-x^{k}), ∇f(xk+1)=∇f(xk)+B(xk+1−xk),

which is called the secant equation (the Taylor series of the gradient itself). In more than one dimension B is underdetermined. In one dimension, solving for B and applying the Newton's step with the updated value is equivalent to the secant method. The various quasi-Newton methods differ in their choice of the solution to the secant equation (in one dimension, all the variants are equivalent).

Natural Gradient Descent

Natural gradient descent is to solve the optimization problem min⁡θL(θ)\min_{\theta} L(\theta)minθ​L(θ) by

θ(t+1)=θ(t+1)−α(t)F−1(θ(t))∇θL(θ(t))\theta^{(t+1)}=\theta^{(t+1)}-\alpha_{(t)}F^{-1}(\theta^{(t)})\nabla_{\theta}L(\theta^{(t)}) θ(t+1)=θ(t+1)−α(t)​F−1(θ(t))∇θ​L(θ(t))

where F−1(θ(t))F^{-1}(\theta^{(t)})F−1(θ(t)) is the inverse of Remiann metric at the point θ(t)\theta^{(t)}θ(t). And Fisher scoring algorithm is a typical application of Natural Gradient Descent to statistics.
Natural gradient descent for manifolds corresponding to exponential families can be implemented as a first-order method through mirror descent (https://www.stat.wisc.edu/~raskutti/publication/MirrorDescent.pdf).

Expectation Maximization Algorithm

Expectation-Maximization algorithm, popularly known as the EM algorithm has become a standard piece in the statistician’s repertoire. It is used in incomplete-data problems or latent-variable problems such as Gaussian mixture model in maximum likelihood estimation. The basic principle behind the EM is that instead of performing a complicated optimization, one augments the observed data with latent data to perform a series of simple optimizations.

Let ℓ(θ∣Yobs)=△log⁡L(θ∣Yobs)\ell(\theta|Y_{obs})\stackrel{\triangle}=\log{L(\theta|Y_{obs})}ℓ(θ∣Yobs​)=△logL(θ∣Yobs​) denote the log-likelihood function of observed datum YobsY_{obs}Yobs​。 We augment the observed data YobsY_{obs}Yobs​ with latent variables ZZZ so that both the complete-data log-likelihood ℓ(θ∣Yobs,Z)\ell(\theta|Y_{obs}, Z)ℓ(θ∣Yobs​,Z) and the conditional predictive distribution f(z∣Yobs,θ)f(z|Y_{obs}, \theta)f(z∣Yobs​,θ) are available. Each iteration of the EM algorithm consists of an expectation step (E-step) and a maximization step (M-step) Specifically, let θ(t)\theta^{(t)}θ(t) be the current best guess at the MLE θ^\hat\thetaθ^. The E-step is to compute the Q function defined by

\begin{align} Q(\theta|\theta^{(t)}) &= \mathbb{E}(\ell(\theta|Y_{obs}, Z)|Y_{obs},\theta^{(t)}) \\ &= \int_{Z}\ell(\theta|Y_{obs}, Z)\times f(z|Y_{obs}, \theta^{(t)})\mathrm{d}z, \end{align}

and the M-step is to maximize Q with respect to θ\thetaθ to obtain

θ(t+1)=arg⁡max⁡θQ(θ∣θ(t)).\theta^{(t+1)}=\arg\max_{\theta} Q(\theta|\theta^{(t)}). θ(t+1)=argθmax​Q(θ∣θ(t)).

  • https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Expectation–maximization_algorithm
  • http://cs229.stanford.edu/notes/cs229-notes8.pdf
Diagram of EM algorithm

Generalized EM Algorithm

Each iteration of the generalized EM algorithm consists of an expectation step (E-step) and a maximization step (M-step) Specifically, let θ(t)\theta^{(t)}θ(t) be the current best guess at the MLE θ^\hat\thetaθ^. The E-step is to compute the Q function defined by

\begin{align} Q(\theta|\theta^{(t)}) &= \mathbb{E}(\ell(\theta|Y_{obs}, Z)|Y_{obs},\theta^{(t)}) \\ &= \int_{Z}\ell(\theta|Y_{obs}, Z)\times f(z|Y_{obs}, \theta^{(t)})\mathrm{d}z, \end{align}

and the another step is to find θ\thetaθ that satisfies

θ(t+1)∈{θ∣Q(θ∣θ(t+1)≥Q(θ∣θ(t))}.\theta^{(t+1)}\in \{\theta|Q(\theta|\theta^{(t+1)} \geq Q(\theta|\theta^{(t)}) \}. θ(t+1)∈{θ∣Q(θ∣θ(t+1)≥Q(θ∣θ(t))}.

It is not to maximize the conditional expectation.

See more on the book The EM Algorithm and Extensions, 2nd Edition by Geoffrey McLachlan , Thriyambakam Krishna.

Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers

Alternating direction method of multipliers is called ADMM shortly. It is aimed to solve the following convex optimization problem:

\begin{align} \min F(x,y) \{&=f(x)+g(y)\} \tag {cost function} \\ Ax+By &=b \tag{constraint} \end{align}

where f(x)f(x)f(x) and g(y)g(y)g(y) is convex; $A and BBB are matrices.

Define the augmented Lagrangian:

Lμ(x,y)=f(x)+g(y)+λT(Ax+By−b)+μ2∥Ax+By−b∥22.L_{\mu}(x,y)=f(x)+g(y)+\lambda^{T}(Ax+By-b)+\frac{\mu}{2}{\|Ax+By-b\|}_{2}^{2}. Lμ​(x,y)=f(x)+g(y)+λT(Ax+By−b)+2μ​∥Ax+By−b∥22​.

It is iterative procedure:

  1. xk+1=arg⁡min⁡xLμ(x,yk,λk);x^{k+1}=\arg\min_{x}L_{\mu}(x,y^{\color{aqua}{k}},\lambda^{\color{aqua}{k}});xk+1=argminx​Lμ​(x,yk,λk);
  2. yk+1=arg⁡min⁡yLμ(xk+1,y,λk);y^{k+1}=\arg\min_{y} L_{\mu}(x^{\color{red}{k+1}}, y, \lambda^{\color{aqua}{k}});yk+1=argminy​Lμ​(xk+1,y,λk);
  3. λk+1=λk+μ(Axk+1+Byk+1−b).\lambda^{k+1} = \lambda^{k}+\mu (Ax^{\color{red}{k+1}} + By^{\color{red}{k+1}}-b).λk+1=λk+μ(Axk+1+Byk+1−b).

Thanks to Professor He Bingsheng who taught me this.\color{aqua}{\text{Thanks to Professor He Bingsheng who taught me this.}}Thanks to Professor He Bingsheng who taught me this.[^9]

Stochastic Gradient Descent

Stochastic gradient descent takes advantages of stochastic or estimated gradient to replace the true gradient in gradient descent. It is stochastic gradient but may not be descent. The name stochastic gradient methods may be more appropriate to call the methods with stochastic gradient. It can date back upto stochastic approximation.

It is aimed to solve the problem with finite sum optimization problem, i.e.

arg⁡min⁡θ1n∑i=1nf(θ∣xi)\arg\min_{\theta}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(\theta|x_i) argθmin​n1​i=1∑n​f(θ∣xi​)

where n<∞n<\inftyn<∞ and {f(θ∣xi)}i=1n\{f(\theta|x_i)\}_{i=1}^{n}{f(θ∣xi​)}i=1n​ are in the same function family and {xi}i=1n⊂Rd\{x_i\}_{i=1}^{n}\subset \mathbb{R}^{d}{xi​}i=1n​⊂Rd are constants while θ∈Rp\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{p}θ∈Rp is the variable vector.

The difficulty is ppp, that the dimension of θ\thetaθ, is tremendous. In other words, the model is overparameterized. And the number nnn is far larger than ppp generally, i.e. n≫p≫dn \gg p\gg dn≫p≫d. What is worse, the functions {f(θ∣xi)}i=1n\{f(\theta|x_i)\}_{i=1}^{n}{f(θ∣xi​)}i=1n​ are not convex in most case.

The stochastic gradient method is defined as

θk+1=θk−αk1m∑j=1m∇f(θk∣xj′)\theta^{k+1}=\theta^{k}-\alpha_{k}\frac{1}{m}\sum_{j=1}^{m}\nabla f(\theta^{k}| x_{j}^{\prime}) θk+1=θk−αk​m1​j=1∑m​∇f(θk∣xj′​)

where xj′x_{j}^{\prime}xj′​ is stochastically draw from {xi}i=1n\{x_i\}_{i=1}^{n}{xi​}i=1n​ and m≪nm\ll nm≪n.

It is the fact m≪nm\ll nm≪n that makes it possible to compute the gradient of finite sum objective function and its side effect is that the objective function is not always descent. There is fluctuations in the total objective function as gradient steps with respect to mini-batches are taken.

The fluctuations in the objective function as gradient steps with respect to mini-batches are taken

An heuristic proposal for avoiding the choice and for modifying the learning rate while the learning task runs is the bold driver (BD) method[^14]. The learning rate increases exponentially if successive steps reduce the objective function fff, and decreases rapidly if an “accident” is encountered (if objective function fff increases), until a suitable value is found. After starting with a small learning rate, its modifications are described by the following equation:

αk+1={ραk,f(θk+1)<f(θk);ηnαk,f(θk+1)>f(θk)using αk, \alpha_{k+1}= \begin{cases} \rho \alpha_{k}, & {f(\theta^{k+1})< f(\theta^{k})}; \\ \eta^n \alpha_{k}, & {f(\theta^{k+1})> f(\theta^{k})} \text{using ${\alpha}_k$}, \end{cases} αk+1​={ραk​,ηnαk​,​f(θk+1)<f(θk);f(θk+1)>f(θk)using αk​,​

where ρ\rhoρ is close to 1 such as ρ=1.1\rho=1.1ρ=1.1 in order to avoid frequent “accidents” because the objective function computation is wasted in these cases, η\etaη is chosen to provide a rapid reduction (η=0.5\eta = 0.5η=0.5), and nnn is the minimum integer such that the reduced rate ηn\eta^nηn succeeds in diminishing the objective function.[^13]

The fact that the sample size is far larger than the dimension of parameter, n≫pn\gg pn≫p, that makes it expensive to compute total objective function f(θ)=∑i=1nf(θ∣xi)f(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}f(\theta|{x}_i)f(θ)=∑i=1n​f(θ∣xi​). Thus it is not clever to determine the learning rate αk\alpha_kαk​ by line search. And most stochastic gradient methods are to find proper step length αk\alpha_{k}αk​ to make it converge at least in convex optimization. The variants of gradient descent such as momentum methods or mirror gradient methods have their stochastic counterparts.

  • It is simplest to set the step length a constant, such as αk=3×10−3 ∀k{\alpha}_k=3\times 10^{-3}\, \forall kαk​=3×10−3∀k.
  • There are decay schemes, i.e. the step length αk{\alpha}_kαk​ diminishes such as αk=αk{\alpha}_k=\frac{\alpha}{k}αk​=kα​, where α\alphaα is constant.
  • And another strategy is to tune the step length adaptively such as AdaGrad, ADAM.

PS\color{lime}{PS}PS: the step length αk\alpha_kαk​ is called learning rate in machine learning and stochastic gradient descent is also named as increment gradient methods in some case.

See the following links for more information on stochastic gradient descent.

Regression Analysis

Regression is a method for studying the relationship between a response variable YYY and a covariates XXX. The covariate is also called a predictor variable or a feature.

Regression is not function fitting. In function fitting, it is well-defined - f(xi)f(x_i)f(xi​) is fixed when xix_ixi​ is fixed; in regression, it is not always so.

Linear regression is the "hello world" in statistical learning. It is the simplest model to fit the datum. We will induce it in the maximum likelihood estimation perspective. See this link for more information https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Regression_analysis.

Ordinary Least Squares

Representation of Ordinary Least Squares

A linear regression model assumes that the regression function E(Y∣X)E(Y|X)E(Y∣X) is linear in the inputs X1,⋯ ,XpX_1,\cdots, X_pX1​,⋯,Xp​. They are simple and often provide an adequate and interpretable description of how the inputs affect the output. Suppose that the datum {(xi,yi)}i=1n\{(x_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^{n}{(xi​,yi​)}i=1n​,

yi=f(xi)+ϵi,{y}_{i} = f({x}_{i})+{\epsilon}_{i}, yi​=f(xi​)+ϵi​,

where the function fff is linear, i.e. f(x)=wTx+bf(x)=w^{T}x + bf(x)=wTx+b. Let ϵ=y−f(x)\epsilon = y - f(x)ϵ=y−f(x).Then E(ϵ∣X)=E(y−f(x)∣x)=0\mathbb{E}(\epsilon|X) = \mathbb{E}(y - f(x)|x)=0E(ϵ∣X)=E(y−f(x)∣x)=0 and the residual errors {ϵi∣ϵi=yi−f(xi)}i=1n\{{\epsilon}_{i}|{\epsilon}_{i} = {y}_{i} - f(x_i)\}_{i=1}^{n}{ϵi​∣ϵi​=yi​−f(xi​)}i=1n​ are i.i.d. in standard Gaussian distribution.

By convention (very important!):

  • x\mathrm{x}x is assumed to be standardized (mean 0, unit variance);
  • y\mathrm{y}y is assumed to be centered.

For the linear regression, we could assume x\mathrm{x}x is in Gaussian distribution.

Evaluation of Ordinary Least Squares

The likelihood of the errors are

L(ϵ1,ϵ2,⋯ ,ϵn)=∏i=1n12πe−ϵi2.L(\epsilon_1,\epsilon_2,\cdots,\epsilon_n)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-\epsilon_i^2}. L(ϵ1​,ϵ2​,⋯,ϵn​)=i=1∏n​2π​1​e−ϵi2​.

In MLE, we have shown that it is equivalent to

arg⁡max⁡∏i=1n12πe−ϵi2=arg⁡min⁡∑i=1nϵi2=arg⁡min⁡∑i=1n(yi−f(xi))2. \arg\max \prod_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{-\epsilon_i^2}=\arg\min\sum_{i=1}^{n}\epsilon_i^2=\arg\min\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-f(x_i))^2. argmaxi=1∏n​2π​1​e−ϵi2​=argmini=1∑n​ϵi2​=argmini=1∑n​(yi​−f(xi​))2.

Linear Regression and Likelihood Maximum Estimation

Optimization of Ordinary Least Squares

For linear regression, the function fff is linear, i.e. f(x)=wTxf(x) = w^Txf(x)=wTx where www is the parameters to tune. Thus ϵi=yi−wTxi\epsilon_i = y_i-w^Tx_iϵi​=yi​−wTxi​ and ∑i=1n(yi−f(xi))2=∑i=1n(yi−wTxi)2\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-f(x_i))^2=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i - w^Tx_i)^2∑i=1n​(yi​−f(xi​))2=∑i=1n​(yi​−wTxi​)2. It is also called residual sum of squares in statistics or objective function in optimization theory. In a compact form,

∑i=1n(yi−wTxi)2=∥Y−Xw∥2 ,(0)\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i - w^T x_i)^2=\|Y-Xw\|^2\,\tag 0, i=1∑n​(yi​−wTxi​)2=∥Y−Xw∥2,(0)

where Y=(y1,y2,⋯ ,yn)T,X=(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)Y=(y_1,y_2,\cdots, y_n)^T, X=(x_1, x_2,\cdots,x_n)Y=(y1​,y2​,⋯,yn​)T,X=(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​). Let the gradient of objective function ∥Y−Xw∥2\|Y-Xw\|^2∥Y−Xw∥2 be 0, i.e.

∇w∥Y−Xw∥2=2XT(Y−Xw)=0 ,(1)\nabla_{w}{\|Y-Xw\|^2}=2X^T(Y-Xw)=0\,\tag 1, ∇w​∥Y−Xw∥2=2XT(Y−Xw)=0,(1)

then we gain that w=(XTX)−1XTYw=(X^TX)^{-1}X^TYw=(XTX)−1XTY if possible.

Note\color{lime}{Note}Note:

  1. the residual error {ϵi}i=1n\{\epsilon_i\}_{i=1}^{n}{ϵi​}i=1n​ are i.i.d. in Gaussian distribution;
  2. the inverse matrix (XTX)−1(X^{T}X)^{-1}(XTX)−1 may not exist in some extreme case.

See more on Wikipedia page.

Ridge Regression and LASSO

When the matrix XTXX^{T}XXTX is not inverse, ordinary least squares does not work. And in ordinary least squares, the parameters www is estimated by MLE rather more general Bayesian estimator.

In the perspective of computation, we would like to consider the regularization technique; In the perspective of Bayesian statistics, we would like to consider more proper prior distribution of the parameters.

Ridge Regression As Regularization

It is to optimize the following objective function with parameter norm penalty

PRSSℓ2=∑i=1n(yi−wTxi)2+λwTw=∥Y−Xw∥2+λ∥w∥2 .(Ridge)PRSS_{\ell_2}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-w^Tx_i)^2+\lambda w^{T}w=\|Y-Xw\|^2+\lambda\|w\|^2\,\tag {Ridge}. PRSSℓ2​​=i=1∑n​(yi​−wTxi​)2+λwTw=∥Y−Xw∥2+λ∥w∥2.(Ridge)

It is called penalized residual sum of squares. Taking derivatives, we solve

∂PRSSℓ2∂w=2XT(Y−Xw)+2λw=0\frac{\partial PRSS_{\ell_2}}{\partial w}=2X^T(Y-Xw)+2\lambda w=0 ∂w∂PRSSℓ2​​​=2XT(Y−Xw)+2λw=0

and we gain that

w=(XTX+λI)−1XTYw=(X^{T}X+\lambda I)^{-1}X^{T}Y w=(XTX+λI)−1XTY

where it is trackable if λ\lambdaλ is large enough.

LASSO as Regularization

LASSO is the abbreviation of Least Absolute Shrinkage and Selection Operator.

  1. It is to minimize the following objective function：

PRSSℓ1=∑i=1n(yi−wTxi)2+λ∥w∥1=∥Y−Xw∥2+λ∥w∥1 .(LASSO)PRSS_{\ell_1}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-w^Tx_i)^2+\lambda{\|w\|}_{1} =\|Y-Xw\|^2+\lambda{\|w\|}_1\,\tag {LASSO}. PRSSℓ1​​=i=1∑n​(yi​−wTxi​)2+λ∥w∥1​=∥Y−Xw∥2+λ∥w∥1​.(LASSO)

  1. the optimization form:

\begin{align} \arg\min_{w}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-w^Tx_i)^2 &\qquad\text{Objective function} \\ \text{subject to}\,{\|w\|}_1 \leq t &\qquad\text{constraint}. \end{align}

  1. the selection form:

\begin{align} \arg\min_{w}{\|w\|}_1 \qquad &\text{Objective function} \\ \text{subject to}\,\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i-w^Tx_i)^2 \leq t \qquad &\text{constraint}. \end{align}

where ∥w∥1=∑i=1n∣wi∣{\|w\|}_1=\sum_{i=1}^{n}|w_i|∥w∥1​=∑i=1n​∣wi​∣ if w=(w1,w2,⋯ ,wn)Tw=(w_1,w_2,\cdots, w_n)^{T}w=(w1​,w2​,⋯,wn​)T.

More solutions to this optimization problem:

Bayesian Perspective

If we suppose the prior distribution of the parameters www is in Gaussian distribution, i.e. fW(w)∝e−λ∥w∥2f_{W}(w)\propto e^{-\lambda\|w\|^{2}}fW​(w)∝e−λ∥w∥2, we will deduce the ridge regression. If we suppose the prior distribution of the parameters www is in Laplacian distribution, i.e. fW(w)∝e−λ∥w∥1f_{W}(w)\propto e^{-\lambda{\|w\|}_1}fW​(w)∝e−λ∥w∥1​, we will deduce LASSO.

Elastic Net

When the sample size of training data nnn is far less than the number of features ppp, the objective function is:

PRSSα=12n∑i=1n(yi−wTxi)2+λ∑j=1pPα(wj),(Elastic net)PRSS_{\alpha}=\frac{1}{2n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(y_i -w^T x_i)^2+\lambda\sum_{j=1}^{p}P_{\alpha}(w_j),\tag {Elastic net} PRSSα​=2n1​i=1∑n​(yi​−wTxi​)2+λj=1∑p​Pα​(wj​),(Elastic net)

where Pα(wj)=α∣wj∣1+12(1−α)(wj)2P_{\alpha}(w_j)=\alpha {|w_j|}_1 + \frac{1}{2}(1-\alpha)(w_j)^2Pα​(wj​)=α∣wj​∣1​+21​(1−α)(wj​)2.

See more on http://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/TALKS/glmnet_webinar.pdf or http://www.princeton.edu/~yc5/ele538_math_data/lectures/model_selection.pdf.

We can deduce it by Bayesian estimation if we suppose the prior distribution of the parameters www is in mixture of Gaussian distribution and Laplacian distribution, i.e.

fW(w)∝e−α∥w∥1−12(1−α)∥w∥2.f_{W}(w)\propto e^{-\alpha{\|w\|}_1-\frac{1}{2}(1-\alpha)\|w\|^{2}}. fW​(w)∝e−α∥w∥1​−21​(1−α)∥w∥2.

See Bayesian lasso regression at http://faculty.chicagobooth.edu/workshops/econometrics/past/pdf/asp047v1.pdf.

Generalized Linear Model

In ordinary least squares, we assume that the errors {ϵi}i=1n\{{\epsilon}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}{ϵi​}i=1n​ are i.i.d. Gaussian, i.e. {ϵi}∼i.i.dN(0,1)\{\epsilon_{i}\} \stackrel{i.i.d}{\sim} N(0,1){ϵi​}∼i.i.dN(0,1) for i∈{1,2,⋯ ,n}i\in\{1,2, \cdots, n\}i∈{1,2,⋯,n}. It is not necessary to assume that they are in Gaussian distribution. In statistics, the generalized linear model (GLM) is a flexible generalization of ordinary linear regression that allows for response variables that have error distribution models other than a normal distribution. The GLM generalizes linear regression by allowing the linear model to be related to the response variable via a link function and by allowing the magnitude of the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value.

Intuition

Ordinary linear regression predicts the expected value of a given unknown quantity (the response variable, a random variable) as a linear combination of a set of observed values (predictors). This implies that a constant change in a predictor leads to a constant change in the response variable (i.e. a linear-response model). This is appropriate when the response variable has a normal distribution (intuitively, when a response variable can vary essentially indefinitely in either direction with no fixed "zero value", or more generally for any quantity that only varies by a relatively small amount, e.g. human heights).

However, these assumptions are inappropriate for some types of response variables. For example, in cases where the response variable is expected to be always positive and varying over a wide range, constant input changes lead to geometrically varying, rather than constantly varying, output changes. As an example, a prediction model might predict that 10 degree temperature decrease would lead to 1,000 fewer people visiting the beach is unlikely to generalize well over both small beaches (e.g. those where the expected attendance was 50 at a particular temperature) and large beaches (e.g. those where the expected attendance was 10,000 at a low temperature). The problem with this kind of prediction model would imply a temperature drop of 10 degrees would lead to 1,000 fewer people visiting the beach, a beach whose expected attendance was 50 at a higher temperature would now be predicted to have the impossible attendance value of −950. Logically, a more realistic model would instead predict a constant rate of increased beach attendance (e.g. an increase in 10 degrees leads to a doubling in beach attendance, and a drop in 10 degrees leads to a halving in attendance). Such a model is termed an exponential-response model (or log-linear model, since the logarithm of the response is predicted to vary linearly).

Model components

In a generalized linear model (GLM), each outcome Y\mathrm{Y}Y of the dependent variables is assumed to be generated from a particular distribution in the exponential family, a large range of probability distributions that includes the normal, binomial, Poisson and gamma distributions, among others. The mean, μ\muμ, of the distribution depends on the independent variables, XXX, through:

E(Y)=μ=g−1(Xβ)\mathbb{E}(Y)=\mu=g^{-1}(X\beta) E(Y)=μ=g−1(Xβ)

where E(Y)\mathbb{E}(Y)E(Y) is the expected value of Y\mathrm{Y}Y; XβX\betaXβ is the linear predictor, a linear combination of unknown parameters β\betaβ; ggg is the link function and g−1g^{-1}g−1 is the inverse function of ggg.

The GLM consists of three elements:

Model components
1. A probability distribution from the exponential family.
2. A linear predictor η=Xβ\eta = X\betaη=Xβ.
3. A link function ggg such that E(Y)=μ=g−1(η)\mathbb{E}(Y) = \mu = g^{−1}(\eta)E(Y)=μ=g−1(η).

Logistic Regression

The logistic distribution:

y=△P(Y=1∣X=x)=11+e−wTx=ewTx1+ewTxy\stackrel{\triangle}=P(Y=1|X=x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-w^{T}x}}=\frac{e^{w^{T}x}}{1+e^{w^{T}x}} y=△P(Y=1∣X=x)=1+e−wTx1​=1+ewTxewTx​

where www is the parameter vector. Thus, we can obtain:

log⁡P(Y=1∣X=x)P(Y≠1∣X=x)=wTx,\log\frac{P(Y=1|X=x)}{P(Y \not= 1|X=x)}=w^{T}x, logP(Y​=1∣X=x)P(Y=1∣X=x)​=wTx,

i.e.

log⁡y1−y=wTx\log\frac{y}{1-y}=w^{T}x log1−yy​=wTx

in theory.

Clustering

There are two different contexts in clustering, depending on how the entities to be clustered are organized. In some cases one starts from an internal representation of each entity (typically an MMM-dimensional vector xix_ixi​ assigned to entity iii) and derives mutual dissimilarities or mutual similarities from the internal representation.In this case one can derive prototypes (or centroids) for each cluster, for example by averaging the characteristics of the contained entities (the vectors). In other cases only an external representation of dissimilarities is available and the resulting model is an undirected and weighted graph of entities connected by edges. From https://www.intelligent-optimization.org/LIONbook/.[^13]

The external representation of dissimilarity will be discussed in Graph Algorithm.
