Principal Component Analysis and Singular Value Decomposition

Singular Value Decomposition

Singular value decomposition is an extension of eigenvector decomposition of a matrix.

For the square matrix Mn×nM_{n\times n}Mn×n​, we can compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors:

Mn×nv=λvM_{n\times n}v=\lambda v Mn×n​v=λv

where the eigenvector v∈Rnv\in \mathbb{R}^nv∈Rn, the eigenvalue λ∈R\lambda \in\mathbb{R}λ∈R. It is equivalent to solve the linear equation system (Mn×n−λIn×n)v=0(M_{n\times n}-\lambda I_{n\times n})v=0(Mn×n​−λIn×n​)v=0 where In×nI_{n\times n}In×n​ is the nnnth order identity matrix. Especially, when Mn×nM_{n\times n}Mn×n​ is symmetrical i.e. MT=MM^T=MMT=M, what are the properties of eigenvalue and eigenvector?

Theorem: All eigenvalues of a symmetrical matrix are real.

Proof: Let AAA be a real symmetrical matrix and Av=λvAv=\lambda vAv=λv. We want to show the eigenvalue λ\lambdaλ is real. Let v⋆v^{\star}v⋆ be conjugate transpose of vvv. v⋆Av=λv⋆v (1)v^{\star}Av=\lambda v^{\star}v\,(1)v⋆Av=λv⋆v(1). If Av=λvAv=\lambda vAv=λv，thus (Av)⋆=(λv)⋆(Av)^{\star}=(\lambda v)^{\star}(Av)⋆=(λv)⋆, i.e. v⋆A=λˉv⋆v^{\star}A=\bar{\lambda}v^{\star}v⋆A=λˉv⋆. We can infer that v⋆Av=λˉv⋆v (2)v^{\star}Av=\bar{\lambda}v^{\star}v\,(2)v⋆Av=λˉv⋆v(2).By comparing the equation (1) and (2), we can obtain that λ=λˉ\lambda=\bar{\lambda}λ=λˉ where λˉ\bar{\lambda}λˉ is the conjugate of λ\lambdaλ.

Theorem: Every symmetrical matrix can be diagonalized.

See more at http://mathworld.wolfram.com/MatrixDiagonalization.html.

When the matrix is rectangle i.e. the number of columns and the number of rows are not equal, what is the counterpart of eigenvalues and eigenvectors? Another question is if every matrix Mm×n∈Rm×nM_{m\times n}\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}Mm×n​∈Rm×n can be written as the sum of rank-1 matrix and how?

Mm×n=∑irpiqi=Pm×rQr×nM_{m\times n}=\sum_{i}^{r}p_i q_i=P_{m\times r}Q_{r\times n} Mm×n​=i∑r​pi​qi​=Pm×r​Qr×n​

where pi∈Rmp_i\in\mathbb{R}^mpi​∈Rm,qi∈Rnq_i\in\mathbb{R}^nqi​∈Rn and rrr is integer. They are from the square matrices Mm×nTMm×n=An×nM_{m\times n}^TM_{m\times n}=A_{n\times n}Mm×nT​Mm×n​=An×n​ and Mm×nMm×nT=Bm×mM_{m\times n}M_{m\times n}^T=B_{m\times m}Mm×n​Mm×nT​=Bm×m​. It is obvious that the matrix AAA and BBB are symmetrical.

Theorem: The matrix AAA and BBB has the same eigenvalues except zero.

Proof: We know that A=Mm×nTMm×nA=M_{m\times n}^TM_{m\times n}A=Mm×nT​Mm×n​ and B=Mm×nMm×nTB=M_{m\times n}M_{m\times n}^TB=Mm×n​Mm×nT​. Let Av=λvAv=\lambda vAv=λv i.e. Mm×nTMm×nv=λvM_{m\times n}^TM_{m\times n} v=\lambda vMm×nT​Mm×n​v=λv, which can be rewritten as Mm×nT(Mm×nv)=λv (1)M_{m\times n}^T(M_{m\times n} v)=\lambda v\,(1)Mm×nT​(Mm×n​v)=λv(1), where v∈Rnv\in\mathbb{R}^nv∈Rn. We multiply the matrix Mm×nM_{m\times n}Mm×n​ in the left of both sides of equation (1), then we obtain Mm×nMm×nT(Mm×nv)=Mm×n(λv)=λ(Mm×nv)M_{m\times n}M_{m\times n}^T(M_{m\times n} v)=M_{m\times n}(\lambda v)=\lambda(M_{m\times n} v)Mm×n​Mm×nT​(Mm×n​v)=Mm×n​(λv)=λ(Mm×n​v).

Theorem: The matrix AAA and BBB are non-negative definite, i.e. <v,Av>≥0,∀v∈Rn\left<v,Av\right>\geq 0, \forall v\in\mathbb{R}^n⟨v,Av⟩≥0,∀v∈Rn and <u,Bu>≥0,∀u∈Rm\left<u,Bu\right>\geq 0, \forall u\in\mathbb{R}^m⟨u,Bu⟩≥0,∀u∈Rm.

Proof: It is <v,Av>=<v,Mm×nTMm×nv>=(Mv)T(Mv)=∥Mv∥22≥0\left<v,Av\right>=\left<v,M_{m\times n}^TM_{m\times n}v\right>=(Mv)^T(Mv)=\|Mv\|_2^2\geq 0⟨v,Av⟩=⟨v,Mm×nT​Mm×n​v⟩=(Mv)T(Mv)=∥Mv∥22​≥0 as well as BBB.

Theorem: Mm×n=Um×mΣm×nVn×nTM_{m\times n}=U_{m\times m}\Sigma_{m\times n} V_{n\times n}^TMm×n​=Um×m​Σm×n​Vn×nT​, where

  • Um×mU_{m\times m}Um×m​ is an m×mm \times mm×m orthogonal matrix;
  • Σm×n\Sigma_{m\times n}Σm×n​ is a diagonal m×nm \times nm×n matrix with non-negative real numbers on the diagonal,
  • Vn×nTV_{n\times n}^TVn×nT​ is the transpose of an n×nn \times nn×n orthogonal matrix.

Graph Algorithms

Graph as Data Structure

Graph is mathematical abstract or generalization of the connection between entries. A graph G{G}G consists of a finite set of vertices V(G)V(G)V(G) and a set of edges E(G)E(G)E(G) consisting of distinct, unordered pairs of vertices, where nodes stand for entities and edges stand for their connections. It is the foundation of network science. It is different from the common data where the feature is nothing except the connection.

Graphs provide a powerful way to represent and exploit these connections. Graphs can be used to model such diverse areas as computer vision, natural language processing, and recommender systems. [^12]

The connections can be directed, weighted even probabilistic.

Definition: Let GGG be a graph with V(G)=1,…,nV(G) = {1,\dots,n}V(G)=1,…,n and E(G)=e1,…,emE(G) = {e_1,\dots, e_m}E(G)=e1​,…,em​. Suppose each edge of GGG is assigned an orientation, which is arbitrary but fixed. The (vertex-edge) incidence matrix of GGG, denoted by Q(G)Q(G)Q(G), is the n×mn \times mn×m matrix defined as follows. The rows and the columns of Q(G)Q(G)Q(G) are indexed by V(G)V(G)V(G) and E(G)E(G)E(G), respectively. The (i,j)(i, j)(i,j)-entry of Q(G)Q(G)Q(G) is 0 if vertex iii and edge eje_jej​ are not incident, and otherwise it is 1 or −1\color{red}{\text{1 or −1}}1 or −1 according as eje_jej​ originates or terminates at iii, respectively. We often denote Q(G)Q(G)Q(G) simply by QQQ. Whenever we mention Q(G)Q(G)Q(G) it is assumed that the edges of GGG are oriented

Definition: Let GGG be a graph with V(G)=1,…,nV(G) = {1,\dots,n}V(G)=1,…,n and E(G)=e1,…,emE(G) = {e_1,\dots, e_m}E(G)=e1​,…,em​.The adjacency matrix of GGG, denoted by A(G)A(G)A(G), is the n×nn\times nn×n matrix defined as follows. The rows and the columns of A(G)A(G)A(G) are indexed by V(G)V(G)V(G). If i≠ji \not= ji​=j then the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j)-entry of A(G)A(G)A(G) is 000 for vertices iii and jjj nonadjacent, and the (i,j)(i, j)(i,j)-entry is 1\color{red}{\text{1}}1 for iii and jjj adjacent. The (i,i)(i,i)(i,i)-entry of A(G)A(G)A(G) is 0 for i=1,…,n.i = 1,\dots,n.i=1,…,n. We often denote A(G)A(G)A(G) simply by AAA. Adjacency Matrix is also used to represent weighted graphs. If the (i,i)(i,i)(i,i)-entry of A(G)A(G)A(G) is wi,jw_{i,j}wi,j​, i.e. A[i][j]=wi,jA[i][j] = w_{i,j}A[i][j]=wi,j​, then there is an edge from vertex iii to vertex jjj with weight www. The Adjacency Matrix of weighted graphs GGG is also called weight matrix of GGG, denoted by W(G)W(G)W(G) or simply by WWW.

Definition: In graph theory, the degree (or valency) of a vertex of a graph is the number of edges incident to the vertex, with loops counted twice. Definition: Let GGG be a graph with V(G)=1,…,nV(G) = {1,\dots,n}V(G)=1,…,n and E(G)=e1,…,emE(G) = {e_1,\dots, e_m}E(G)=e1​,…,em​.The Laplacian matrix of GGG, denoted by L(G)L(G)L(G), is the n×nn\times nn×n matrix defined as follows. The (i,i)(i,i)(i,i)-entry of L(G)L(G)L(G) is di\color{red}{d_i}di​, the degree of the vertex iii, for i=1,…,n.i = 1,\dots,n.i=1,…,n. In other words, the (i,i)(i,i)(i,i)-entry of L(G)L(G)L(G), L(G)i,jL(G)_{i,j}L(G)i,j​, is defined by

L(G)i,j={deg⁡(Vi)if i=j,−1if i≠j and Vi and Vj is adjacent,0otherwise.L(G)_{i,j} = \begin{cases} \deg(V_i) & \text{if $i=j$,}\\ -1 & \text{if $i\not= j$ and $V_i$ and $V_j$ is adjacent,} \\ 0 & \text{otherwise.}\end{cases} L(G)i,j​=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​deg(Vi​)−10​if i=j,if i​=j and Vi​ and Vj​ is adjacent,otherwise.​

Laplacian matrix of a graph GGG with weighted matrix WWW is LW=D−W{L^{W}=D-W}LW=D−W, where DDD is the degree matrix of GGG. We often denote L(G)L(G)L(G) simply by LLL.

Definition: A directed graph (or digraph) is a set of vertices and a collection of directed edges that each connects an ordered pair of vertices. We say that a directed edge points from the first vertex in the pair and points to the second vertex in the pair. We use the names 0 through V-1 for the vertices in a V-vertex graph. A* Algorithm

In computer science, A* (pronounced "A star") is a computer algorithm that is widely used in pathfinding and graph traversal, which is the process of finding a path between multiple points, called "nodes". It enjoys widespread use due to its performance and accuracy. However, in practical travel-routing systems, it is generally outperformed by algorithms which can pre-process the graph to attain better performance, although other work has found A* to be superior to other approaches. It is draw from Wikipedia page on A* algorithm.

First we learn the Dijkstra's algorithm. Dijkstra's algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a graph, which may represent, for example, road networks. It was conceived by computer scientist Edsger W. Dijkstra in 1956 and published three years later.

Graph Kernel

Like kernels in kernel methods, graph kernel is used as functions measuring the similarity of pairs of graphs. They allow kernelized learning algorithms such as support vector machines to work directly on graphs, without having to do feature extraction to transform them to fixed-length, real-valued feature vectors.

Spectral Clustering Algorithm

Spectral method is the kernel tricks applied to locality preserving projections as to reduce the dimension, which is as the data preprocessing for clustering.

In multivariate statistics and the clustering of data, spectral clustering techniques make use of the spectrum (eigenvalues) of the similarity matrix of the data to perform dimensionality reduction before clustering in fewer dimensions. The similarity matrix is provided as an input and consists of a quantitative assessment of the relative similarity of each pair of points in the data set.

Similarity matrix is to measure the similarity between the input features {xi}i=1n⊂Rp\{\mathbf{x}_i\}_{i=1}^{n}\subset\mathbb{R}^{p}{xi​}i=1n​⊂Rp. For example, we can use Gaussian kernel function

f(xi,xj)=exp(−∥xi−xj∥222σ2)f(\mathbf{x_i},\mathbf{x}_j)=exp(-\frac{{\|\mathbf{x_i}-\mathbf{x}_j\|}_2^2}{2\sigma^2}) f(xi​,xj​)=exp(−2σ2∥xi​−xj​∥22​​)

to measure the similarity of inputs. The element of similarity matrix SSS is Si,j=exp(−∥xi−xj∥222σ2)S_{i,j}=exp(-\frac{{\|\mathbf{x_i}-\mathbf{x}_j\|}_2^2}{2\sigma^2})Si,j​=exp(−2σ2∥xi​−xj​∥22​​). Thus SSS is symmetrical, i.e. Si,j=Sj,iS_{i,j}=S_{j,i}Si,j​=Sj,i​ for i,j∈{1,2,…,n}i,j\in\{1,2,\dots,n\}i,j∈{1,2,…,n}. If the sample size n≫pn\gg pn≫p, the storage of similarity matrix is much larger than the original input {xi}i=1n\{\mathbf{x}_i\}_{i=1}^{n}{xi​}i=1n​, when we would only preserve the entries above some values. The Laplacian matrix is defined by L=D−SL=D-SL=D−S where D=Diag{D1,D2,…,Dn}D=Diag\{D_1,D_2,\dots,D_n\}D=Diag{D1​,D2​,…,Dn​} and Di=∑j=1nSi,j=∑j=1nexp(−∥xi−xj∥222σ2)D_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}S_{i,j}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}exp(-\frac{{\|\mathbf{x_i}-\mathbf{x}_j\|}_2^2}{2\sigma^2})Di​=∑j=1n​Si,j​=∑j=1n​exp(−2σ2∥xi​−xj​∥22​​).

Then we can apply principal component analysis to the Laplacian matrix LLL to reduce the data dimension. After that we can perform K−meansK-meansK−means or other clustering.

Stacking

Stacked generalization (or stacking) is a different way of combining multiple models, that introduces the concept of a meta learner. Although an attractive idea, it is less widely used than bagging and boosting. Unlike bagging and boosting, stacking may be (and normally is) used to combine models of different types. The procedure is as follows:

  1. Split the training set into two disjoint sets.
  2. Train several base learners on the first part.
  3. Test the base learners on the second part.
  4. Using the predictions from 3) as the inputs, and the correct responses as the outputs, train a higher level learner.

Note that steps 1) to 3) are the same as cross-validation, but instead of using a winner-takes-all approach, we combine the base learners, possibly nonlinearly.

In theory, we do not clearly understand how to design more robust and efficient network architecture; in practice, we can apply it to diverse fields. Perceptron

Perceptron can be seen as a generalized linear model. In mathematics, it is a map

f:Rn→R.f:\mathbb{R}^n\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. f:Rn→R.

It can be decomposed into 222 steps:

  1. Aggregate all the information: z=∑i=1nwixi+b0=(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn,1)⋅(w1,w2,⋯ ,wn,b0)T.z=\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_ix_i+b_0=(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n,1)\cdot (w_1,w_2,\cdots,w_n,b_0)^{T}.z=∑i=1n​wi​xi​+b0​=(x1​,x2​,⋯,xn​,1)⋅(w1​,w2​,⋯,wn​,b0​)T.
  2. Transform the information to activate something: y=σ(z)y=\sigma(z)y=σ(z), where σ\sigmaσ is nonlinear such as step function.

Activation function

The nonlinear function σ\sigmaσ is conventionally called activation function. There are some activation functions in history.

  • Sign function

    f(x)={1,if x>0−1,if x<0f(x)=\begin{cases}1,&\text{if $x > 0$}\\ -1,&\text{if $x < 0$}\end{cases} f(x)={1,−1,​if x>0if x<0​

  • Step function

    f(x)={1,if x≥00,otherwisef(x)=\begin{cases}1,&\text{if $x\geq0$}\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases} f(x)={1,0,​if x≥0otherwise​

  • Sigmoid function

    σ(x)=11+e−x.\sigma(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-x}}. σ(x)=1+e−x1​.

  • Radical base function

    ρ(x)=e−β(x−x0)2.\rho(x)=e^{-\beta(x-x_0)^2}. ρ(x)=e−β(x−x0​)2.

  • TanH function

    tanh(x)=2σ(2x)−1=21+e−2x−1.tanh(x)=2\sigma(2x)-1=\frac{2}{1+e^{-2x}}-1. tanh(x)=2σ(2x)−1=1+e−2x2​−1.

  • ReLU function

    ReLU(x)=(x)+=max⁡{0,x}={x,if x≥00,otherwise.ReLU(x)={(x)}_{+}=\max\{0,x\}=\begin{cases}x,&\text{if $x\geq 0$}\\ 0,&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}. ReLU(x)=(x)+​=max{0,x}={x,0,​if x≥0otherwise​.

Learning algorithm

We draw it from the Wikipedia page. Learning is to find optimal parameters of the model. Before that, we must feed data into the model. The training data of nnn sample size is

D={(xi,di)}i=1nD=\{(\mathbf{x}_i,d_i)\}_{i=1}^{n} D={(xi​,di​)}i=1n​

where

  • xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​ is the nnn-dimensional input vector;
  • did_idi​ is the desired output value of the perceptron for that input xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​.
  1. Initialize the weights and the threshold. Weights may be initialized to 0 or to a small random value. In the example below, we use 0.
  2. For each example jjj in our training set DDD, perform the following steps over the input xj\mathbf{x}_{j}xj​ and desired output djd_{j}dj​:

    • Calculate the actual output：

      \begin{align} y_{j}(t) & =f[\mathbf{w}(t)\cdot\mathbf{x}_{j}]\\ ​ & =f[w_{0}(t)x_{j,0}+w_{1}(t)x_{j,1}+w_{2}(t)x_{j,2}+\dotsb +w_{n}(t)x_{j,n}] \end{align}

    • Update the weights: wi(t+1)=wi(t)+r⋅(dj−yj(t))x(j,i),w_{i}(t+1)=w_{i}(t)+r\cdot (d_{j}-y_{j}(t))x_{(j,i)},wi​(t+1)=wi​(t)+r⋅(dj​−yj​(t))x(j,i)​, for all features [0≤i≤n][0\leq i\leq n][0≤i≤n], is the learning rate.

  3. For offline learning, the second step may be repeated until the iteration error 1s∑j=1s∣dj−yj(t)∣\frac{1}{s}\sum_{j=1}^{s}|d_{j}-y_{j}(t)|s1​∑j=1s​∣dj​−yj​(t)∣ is less than a user-specified error threshold γ\gammaγ, or a predetermined number of iterations have been completed, where s is again the size of the sample set.

Note\color{lime}{Note}Note: the perceptron model is linear classifier, i.e. the training data set DDD is linearly separable such that the learning algorithm can converge.

Feedforward Neural Network

Representation of Feedforward Neural Network

Given that the function of a single neuron is rather simple, it subdivides the input space into two regions by a hyperplane, the complexity must come from having more layers of neurons involved in a complex action (like recognizing your grandmother in all possible situations).The "squashing" functions introduce critical nonlinearities in the system, without their presence multiple layers would still create linear functions. Organized layers are very visible in the human cerebral cortex, the part of our brain which plays a key role in memory, attention, perceptual awareness, thought, language, and consciousness.[^13]

The feedforward neural network is also called multilayer perceptron. The best way to create complex functions from simple functions is by composition. In mathematics, it can be considered as multi-layered non-linear composite function:

X→σ∘(W1X+b1)=H1→σ∘(W2H1+b2)=H2→⋯σ(WH+b)=yX\to \sigma\circ (W_1X+b_1)=H_1\to \sigma\circ(W_2 H_1+b_2)=H_2 \to\cdots \sigma(WH+b)=y X→σ∘(W1​X+b1​)=H1​→σ∘(W2​H1​+b2​)=H2​→⋯σ(WH+b)=y

where the notation ∘\circ∘, M1,b1,M2,b2,⋯ ,W,bM_1,b_1,M_2,b_2,\cdots, W,bM1​,b1​,M2​,b2​,⋯,W,b mean pointwise operation, the parameters in the affine mapping, respectively. Thus the data flow in the form of the chain:

\begin{align} f = H_1 \circ {H_2}\circ \cdots \circ{\sigma} \qquad &\text{Composite form} \\ X\stackrel{\sigma}\to H_1 \stackrel{\sigma}\to H_2 \stackrel{\sigma} \to \cdots\stackrel{\sigma}\to\,y \qquad &\text{Hierarchy form} \\ \mathbb{R}^p\to \mathbb{R}^{l_1}\to \mathbb{R}^{l_2}\to \cdots\to \mathbb{R} \qquad& \text{Dimension} \end{align}

where the circle notation ∘\circ∘ means forward composite or as the input of afterward operation. In hierarchy form, we omit the affine map. It is can be written in the recursive form:

\begin{align} \mathbf{z}_{i} &= W_{i}H_{i-1}+b_i, \\ H_{i} &=\sigma\circ (\mathbf{z}_{i}), \forall i\{1,2,\dots,D\} \tag 3 \end{align}

where H0=X∈RpH_{0}=X\in\mathbb{R}^pH0​=X∈Rp, bib_ibi​ is a vector and WiW_{i}Wi​ is matrix. And the number of recursive times DDD is called the depth of network.

  1. In the first layer, we feed the input vector X∈RpX\in\mathbb{R}^{p}X∈Rp and connect it to each unit in the next layer W1X+b1∈Rl1W_1X+b_1\in\mathbb{R}^{l_1}W1​X+b1​∈Rl1​ where W1∈Rn×l1,b1∈Rl1W_1\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times l_1}, b_1\in\mathbb{R}^{l_1}W1​∈Rn×l1​,b1​∈Rl1​. The output of the first layer is H1=σ∘(M1X+b)H_1=\sigma\circ(M_1X+b)H1​=σ∘(M1​X+b), or in another word the output of jjjth unit in the first (hidden) layer is hj=σ(W1X+b1)jh_j=\sigma{(W_1X+b_1)}_jhj​=σ(W1​X+b1​)j​ where (W1X+b1)j{(W_1X+b_1)}_j(W1​X+b1​)j​ is the jjjth element of l1l_1l1​-dimensional vector W1X+b1W_1X+b_1W1​X+b1​.
  2. In the second layer, its input is the output of first layer,H1H_1H1​, and apply linear map to it: W2H1+b2∈Rl2W_2H_1+b_2\in\mathbb{R}^{l_2}W2​H1​+b2​∈Rl2​, where W2∈Rl1×l2,b2∈Rl2W_2\in\mathbb{R}^{l_1\times l_2}, b_2\in\mathbb{R}^{l_2}W2​∈Rl1​×l2​,b2​∈Rl2​. The output of the second layer is H2=σ∘(W2H1+b2)H_2=\sigma\circ(W_2H_1+b_2)H2​=σ∘(W2​H1​+b2​), or in another word the output of jjjth unit in the second (hidden) layer is hj=σ(W2H1+b2)jh_j=\sigma{(W_2H_1+b_2)}_jhj​=σ(W2​H1​+b2​)j​ where (W2H1+b2)j{(W_2H_1+b_2)}_j(W2​H1​+b2​)j​ is the jjjth element of l2l_2l2​-dimensional vector W2H1+b2W_2H_1+b_2W2​H1​+b2​.
  3. The map between the second layer and the third layer is similar to (1) and (2): the linear maps datum to different dimensional space and the nonlinear maps extract better representations.
  4. In the last layer, suppose the input data is H∈RlH\in\mathbb{R}^{l}H∈Rl. The output may be vector or scalar values and WWW may be a matrix or vector as well as yyy.

The ordinary feedforward neural networks take the sigmoid function σ(x)=11+e−x\sigma(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-x}}σ(x)=1+e−x1​ as the nonlinear activation function while the RBF networks take the Radial basis function as the activation function such as σ(x)=ec∥x∥22\sigma(x)=e^{c{\|x\|}_2^2}σ(x)=ec∥x∥22​.

In theory, the universal approximation theorem show the power of feedforward neural network if we take some proper activation functions such as sigmoid function.

Evaluation and Optimization in Multilayer Perceptron

The problem is how to find the optimal parameters W1,b1,W2,b2,⋯ ,W,bW_1, b_1, W_2, b_2,\cdots, W, bW1​,b1​,W2​,b2​,⋯,W,b ? The multilayer perceptron is as one example of supervised learning, which means that we feed datum D={(xi,di)}i=1nD=\{(\mathbf{x_i},d_i)\}_{i=1}^{n}D={(xi​,di​)}i=1n​ to it and evaluate it.

The general form of the evaluation is given by:

J(θ)=1n∑i=1nL[f(xi∣θ),di]J(\theta)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{L}[f(\mathbf{x}_i|\theta),\mathbf{d}_i] J(θ)=n1​i=1∑n​L[f(xi​∣θ),di​]

where di\mathbf{d}_idi​ is the desired value of the input xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​ and θ\thetaθ is the parameters of multilayer perceptron. The notation f(xi∣θ)f(\mathbf{x}_i|\theta)f(xi​∣θ) is the output given paramaters θ\thetaθ. The function L\mathbb{L}L is loss function to measure the discrpency between the predicted value f(xi∣θ)f(\mathbf{x}_i|\theta)f(xi​∣θ) and the desired value di\mathbf{d}_idi​.

In general, the number of parameters θ\thetaθ is less than the sample size nnn. And the objective function J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ) is not convex.

We will solve it in the next section Backpropagation, Optimization and Regularization.

Evaluation for different tasks

Evaluation is to judge the models with different parameters in some sense via objective function. In maximum likelihood estimation, it is likelihood or log-likelihood; in parameter estimation, it is bias or mean square error; in regression, it depends on the case.

In machine learning, evaluation is aimed to measure the discrepancy between the predicted values and trues value by loss function. It is expected to be continuous smooth and differential but it is snot necessary. The principle is the loss function make the optimization or learning tractable. For classification, the loss function always is cross entropy; for regression, the loss function can be any norm function such as the ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm; in probability models, the loss function always is joint probability or logarithm of joint probability.

In classification, the last layer is to predict the degree of belief of the labels via softmax function, i.e.

softmax(z)=(exp⁡(z1)∑i=1nexp⁡(zi),exp⁡(z2)∑i=1nexp⁡(zi),⋯ ,exp⁡(zn)∑i=1nexp⁡(zi))softmax(z)=(\frac{\exp(z_1)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\exp(z_i)},\frac{\exp(z_2)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n} \exp(z_i)}, \cdots, \frac{\exp(z_n)}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\exp(z_i)}) softmax(z)=(∑i=1n​exp(zi​)exp(z1​)​,∑i=1n​exp(zi​)exp(z2​)​,⋯,∑i=1n​exp(zi​)exp(zn​)​)

where nnn is the number of total classes. The labels are encoded as the one hot vector such as d=(1,0,0,⋯ ,0)\mathrm{d}=(1,0,0,\cdots,0)d=(1,0,0,⋯,0). The cross entropy is defined as:

H(d,p)=−∑i=1ndilog⁡(pi)=∑i=1ndilog⁡(1pi),\mathbf{H}(d,p)=-\sum_{i=1}^{n}d_i\log(p_i)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}d_i\log(\frac{1}{p_i}),H(d,p)=−i=1∑n​di​log(pi​)=i=1∑n​di​log(pi​1​),

where did_idi​ is the iiith element of the one-hot vector ddd and pi=exp⁡(zi)∑j=1nexp⁡(zj)p_i=\frac{\exp(z_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^{n}\exp(z_j)}pi​=∑j=1n​exp(zj​)exp(zi​)​ for all i=1,2…,n.i=1,2\dots, n.i=1,2…,n.

Suppose d=(1,0,0,⋯ ,0)\mathrm{d}=(1,0,0,\cdots,0)d=(1,0,0,⋯,0), the cross entropy is H(d,p)=−log⁡(p1)=log⁡∑i=1nexp⁡(zi)−z1\mathbf{H}(d,p)=-\log(p_1)=\log \sum_{i=1}^{n}\exp(z_i)-z_1H(d,p)=−log(p1​)=log∑i=1n​exp(zi​)−z1​. The cost function is 1n∑i=1nH(di,pi)\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\mathbf{H}(d^{i},p^{i})n1​∑i=1n​H(di,pi) in the training data set {(xi,di)}i=1n\{(\mathbf{x}_i,d^i)\}_{i=1}^{n}{(xi​,di)}i=1n​ where xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​ is the features of iiith sample and did^idi is the desired true target label encoded in one-hot vector meanwhile pip^{i}pi is the predicted label of xi\mathbf{x}_ixi​. See the following links for more information on cross entropy and softmax.

In regression, the loss function may simply be the squared ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm, i.e. L(d,p)=(d−p)2\mathbb{L}(d,p)=(d-p)^{2}L(d,p)=(d−p)2 where ddd is the desired target and ppp is the predicted result. And the cost function is mean squared error:

J(θ)=1n∑i=1n[f(xi∣θ)−di]2.J(\theta)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}[f(\mathbf{x}_i|\theta)-\mathrm{d}_i]^2. J(θ)=n1​i=1∑n​[f(xi​∣θ)−di​]2.

It is important to choose or design loss function or more generally objective function, which can select variable as LASSO or confirm prior information as Bayesian estimation. Except the representation or model, it is the objective function that affects the usefulness of learning algorithms.

Backpropagation, Training and Regularization

Backpropagation

Automatic differentiation is the generic name for techniques that use the computational representation of a function to produce analytic values for the derivatives. Automatic differentiation techniques are founded on the observation that any function, no matter how complicated, is evaluated by performing a sequence of simple elementary operations involving just one or two arguments at a time. Backpropagation is one special case of automatic differentiation, i.e. reverse-mode automatic differentiation.

The backpropagation procedure to compute the gradient of an objective function with respect to the weights of a multilayer stack of modules is nothing more than a practical application of the chain rule for derivatives. The key insight is that the derivative (or gradient) of the objective with respect to the input of a module can be computed by working backwards from the gradient with respect to the output of that module (or the input of the subsequent module). The backpropagation equation can be applied repeatedly to propagate gradients through all modules, starting from the output at the top (where the network produces its prediction) all the way to the bottom (where the external input is fed). Once these gradients have been computed, it is straightforward to compute the gradients with respect to the weights of each module.[^10]

Suppose that f(x)=σ∘(WH+b)f(x)={\sigma}\circ(WH + b)f(x)=σ∘(WH+b),where H=σ∘(W4H3+b4)H=\sigma\circ(W_4H_3 + b_4)H=σ∘(W4​H3​+b4​), H3=σ∘(W3H2+b3)H_3=\sigma\circ(W_3H_2 + b_3)H3​=σ∘(W3​H2​+b3​),H2=σ∘(W2H1+b2),H_2=\sigma\circ(W_2H_1 + b_2),H2​=σ∘(W2​H1​+b2​), H1=σ∘(W1x+b1)H_1=\sigma\circ(W_1x + b_1)H1​=σ∘(W1​x+b1​), we want to compute the gradient L(x0,d0)=∥f(x0)−d0∥22L(x_0,d_0)=\|f(x_0)-d_0\|^{2}_2L(x0​,d0​)=∥f(x0​)−d0​∥22​ with respect to all weights W1,W2,W3,WW_1,W_2,W_3,WW1​,W2​,W3​,W:

∂L(x0,d0)∂Wni=∂L(x0,d0)∂f(x0)∂f(x0)∂Wni∀i∈{1,2,…,ln},∀ n∈{1,2,3,4}\frac{\partial L(x_0,d_0)}{\partial W_n^i}=\frac{\partial L(x_0,d_0)}{\partial f(x_0)}\frac{\partial f(x_0)}{\partial W_n^i}\forall i\in\{1,2,\dots,l_n\}, \forall\,n\in\{1,2,3,4\} ∂Wni​∂L(x0​,d0​)​=∂f(x0​)∂L(x0​,d0​)​∂Wni​∂f(x0​)​∀i∈{1,2,…,ln​},∀n∈{1,2,3,4}

and it is fundamental to compute the gradient with respect to the last layer as below.

  • the gradient of loss function with respect to the prediction function:

∂L(x0,d0)∂f(x0)=2[f(x0)−d0],\frac{\partial L(x_0,d_0)}{\partial f(x_0)}=2[f(x_0)-d_0], ∂f(x0​)∂L(x0​,d0​)​=2[f(x0​)−d0​],

  • the gradient of each unit in prediction function with respect to the weight in the last layer:

∂fj(x0)∂Wj=∂σ(WjH+bj)∂Wj=σ′(WjH+bj)H  ∀j∈{1,2,…,l},\frac{\partial f^{j}(x_0)}{\partial W^j}= \frac{\partial \sigma(W^jH+b^j)}{\partial W^j}= {\sigma}^{\prime}(W^jH+b^j) H \,\,\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l\}, ∂Wj∂fj(x0​)​=∂Wj∂σ(WjH+bj)​=σ′(WjH+bj)H∀j∈{1,2,…,l},

  • the gradient of prediction function with respect to the last hidden state:

∂fj(x0)∂H=∂σ(WjH+bj)∂H=σ′(WjH+bj)Wj  ∀j∈{1,2,…,l},\frac{\partial f^{j}(x_0)}{\partial H} = \frac{\partial \sigma(W^jH+b^j)}{\partial H} = {\sigma}^{\prime}(W^jH+b^j) W^j \,\,\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l\}, ∂H∂fj(x0​)​=∂H∂σ(WjH+bj)​=σ′(WjH+bj)Wj∀j∈{1,2,…,l},

where fj(x0)f^{j}(x_0)fj(x0​), WjW^{j}Wj, bjb^jbj and σ′(z)\sigma^{\prime}(z)σ′(z)is the jjjth element of f(x0)f(x_0)f(x0​), the jjj-th row of matrix WWW, the jjjth element of vector bbb and dσ(z)dz\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigma(z)}{\mathrm{d} z}dzdσ(z)​, respectively.

The Architecture of Feedforward Neural Networks
Each connection ,the black line, is attached with a weight parameter.

Recall the chain rule with more variables:

∂f(m(x0),n(x0))∂x0=∂f(m(x0),n(x0))∂m(x0)∂m(x0)∂x0+∂f(m(x0),n(x0))∂n(x0)∂n(x0)∂x0.\frac{\partial f(m(x_0),n(x_0))}{\partial x_0}=\frac{\partial f(m(x_0),n(x_0))}{\partial m(x_0)}\frac{\partial m(x_0)}{\partial x_0} + \frac{\partial f(m(x_0),n(x_0))}{\partial n(x_0)}\frac{\partial n(x_0)}{\partial x_0}. ∂x0​∂f(m(x0​),n(x0​))​=∂m(x0​)∂f(m(x0​),n(x0​))​∂x0​∂m(x0​)​+∂n(x0​)∂f(m(x0​),n(x0​))​∂x0​∂n(x0​)​.

Similarly , we can compute following gradients:

∂Hj∂W4j=∂σ(W4jH3+b4j)∂W4j=σ′(W4jH3+b4j)H3∀j∈{1,2,…,l};\frac{\partial H^j}{\partial W_4^j} =\frac{\partial \sigma(W_4^j H_3+b_4^j)}{\partial W_4^j} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_4^j H_3+b_4^j)H_3 \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l\}; ∂W4j​∂Hj​=∂W4j​∂σ(W4j​H3​+b4j​)​=σ′(W4j​H3​+b4j​)H3​∀j∈{1,2,…,l};

∂Hj∂H3=∂σ(W4jH3+b4j)∂H3=σ′(W4jH3+b4j)W4j∀j∈{1,2,…,l4};\frac{\partial H^j}{\partial H_3} =\frac{\partial \sigma(W_4^j H_3+b_4^j)}{\partial H_3} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_4^j H_3+b_4^j)W_4^j \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_4\}; ∂H3​∂Hj​=∂H3​∂σ(W4j​H3​+b4j​)​=σ′(W4j​H3​+b4j​)W4j​∀j∈{1,2,…,l4​};

∂H3j∂W3j=∂σ(W3jH2+b3j)∂W3j=σ′(W3jH2+b3j)H2∀j∈{1,2,…,l3};\frac{\partial H_3^j}{\partial W_3^j}=\frac{\partial \sigma(W_3^j H_2+b_3^j)}{\partial W_3^j} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_3^j H_2+b_3^j)H_2 \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_3\}; ∂W3j​∂H3j​​=∂W3j​∂σ(W3j​H2​+b3j​)​=σ′(W3j​H2​+b3j​)H2​∀j∈{1,2,…,l3​};

∂H3j∂H2=∂σ(W3jH2+b3j)∂H2=σ′(W3jH2+b3j)W3j∀j∈{1,2,…,l3};\frac{\partial H_3^j}{\partial H_2} =\frac{\partial \sigma(W_3^j H_2+b_3^j)}{\partial H_2} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_3^j H_2+b_3^j)W_3^j \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_3\}; ∂H2​∂H3j​​=∂H2​∂σ(W3j​H2​+b3j​)​=σ′(W3j​H2​+b3j​)W3j​∀j∈{1,2,…,l3​};

∂H2j∂W2j=∂σ(W2jH1+b2j)∂W2j=σ′(W2jH1+b2j)H1∀j∈{1,2,…,l2};\frac{\partial H_2^j}{\partial W_2^j}=\frac{\partial \sigma(W_2^j H_1+b_2^j)}{\partial W_2^j} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_2^j H_1+b_2^j)H_1 \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_2\}; ∂W2j​∂H2j​​=∂W2j​∂σ(W2j​H1​+b2j​)​=σ′(W2j​H1​+b2j​)H1​∀j∈{1,2,…,l2​};

∂H2j∂H1=∂σ(W2jH1+b2j)∂H1=σ′(W2jH1+b2j)W2j∀j∈{1,2,…,l2};\frac{\partial H_2^j}{\partial H_1} =\frac{\partial \sigma(W_2^j H_1+b_2^j)}{\partial H_1} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_2^j H_1+b_2^j)W_2^j \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_2\}; ∂H1​∂H2j​​=∂H1​∂σ(W2j​H1​+b2j​)​=σ′(W2j​H1​+b2j​)W2j​∀j∈{1,2,…,l2​};

∂H1j∂W1j=∂σ(W1jx0+b1j)∂W1j=σ′(W1jx0+b1j)x0∀j∈{1,2,…,l1}.\frac{\partial H_1^j}{\partial W_1^j}=\frac{\partial \sigma(W_1^j x_0+b_1^j)}{\partial W_1^j} =\sigma^{\prime}(W_1^j x_0+b_1^j)x_0 \qquad\forall j\in\{1,2,\dots,l_1\}. ∂W1j​∂H1j​​=∂W1j​∂σ(W1j​x0​+b1j​)​=σ′(W1j​x0​+b1j​)x0​∀j∈{1,2,…,l1​}.

The multilayer perceptron f(x)f(x)f(x) can be written in a chain form:

X→σH1→σH2→σH3→σH4→σH→σ f(x)X→W1X→W2H1→W3H2→W4H3→WH→yRp→Rl1→Rl2→Rl3→Rl→RoX\stackrel{\sigma}{\to} H_1 \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} H_2\stackrel{\sigma} \to H_3 \stackrel{\sigma} \to H_4 \stackrel{\sigma} \to H\stackrel{\sigma}\to\, f(x) \\ X\rightarrow W_1 X \rightarrow W_2H_1 \rightarrow W_3H_2 \rightarrow W_4H_3 \rightarrow WH \rightarrow y \\ \mathbb{R}^{p}\to \mathbb{R}^{l_1}\to \mathbb{R}^{l_2}\to \mathbb{R}^{l_3}\to \mathbb{R}^{l}\to \mathbb{R}^{o} X→σH1​→σH2​→σH3​→σH4​→σH→σf(x)X→W1​X→W2​H1​→W3​H2​→W4​H3​→WH→yRp→Rl1​→Rl2​→Rl3​→Rl→Ro

while the backpropagation to compute the gradient is in the reverse order:

∂y∂W→∂y∂H→∂H∂W4→∂H∂H3→∂H3∂W3→∂H3∂H2→∂H2∂W2→∂H2∂W1→∂H1∂W1.\frac{\partial y}{\partial W}\to \frac{\partial y}{\partial H}\to \frac{\partial H}{\partial W_4}\to \frac{\partial H}{\partial H_3}\to \frac{\partial H_3}{\partial W_3}\to \frac{\partial H_3}{\partial H_2}\to \frac{\partial H_2}{\partial W_2}\to \frac{\partial H_2}{\partial W_1}\to \frac{\partial H_1}{\partial W_1}. ∂W∂y​→∂H∂y​→∂W4​∂H​→∂H3​∂H​→∂W3​∂H3​​→∂H2​∂H3​​→∂W2​∂H2​​→∂W1​∂H2​​→∂W1​∂H1​​.

In general, the gradient of any weight can be computed by backpropagation algorithm. The first step is to compute the gradient of loss function with respect to the output f(x0)=y∈Rof(x_0)=y\in\mathbb{R}^{o}f(x0​)=y∈Ro, i.e. ∂L(x0,d0)∂f(x0)=2(f(x0)−d0)=2(σ∘(WH+b)−d0)\frac{\partial L(x_0, d_0)}{\partial f(x_0)}=2(f(x_0)-d_0)=2(\sigma\circ(WH+b)-d_0)∂f(x0​)∂L(x0​,d0​)​=2(f(x0​)−d0​)=2(σ∘(WH+b)−d0​) , of which the iiith element is 2(yi−d0i)=2(σ(WiH+bi)−d0i) ∀i{1,2,…,o}2(y^{i}-d_0^i)=2(\sigma(W^{i}H+b^{i})-d_0^{i})\,\forall i\{1,2,\dots,o\}2(yi−d0i​)=2(σ(WiH+bi)−d0i​)∀i{1,2,…,o}. Thus

∂L(x0,d0)∂Wi=∂L(x0,d0)∂yi∂yi∂Wi=2(yi−d0i)σ′(WiH+bi)H.\frac{\partial L(x_0, d_0)}{\partial W^{i}}=\frac{\partial L(x_0, d_0)}{\partial y^{i}}\frac{\partial y^{i}}{\partial W^{i}}=2(y^{i}-d_0^i)\sigma^{\prime}(W^iH+b^i)H. ∂Wi∂L(x0​,d0​)​=∂yi∂L(x0​,d0​)​∂Wi∂yi​=2(yi−d0i​)σ′(WiH+bi)H.

Thus we can compute all the gradients of WWW columns. Note that HHH has been computed through forwards propagation in that layer.

And H=σ∘(W4H3+b3)H=\sigma\circ(W_4H_3+b_3)H=σ∘(W4​H3​+b3​), of which the iiith element is Hi=σ(W4H3+b4)i=σ(W4iH3+b4i)H^{i}=\sigma(W_4 H_3 +b_4)^{i}=\sigma(W_4^{i} H_3+b_4^{i})Hi=σ(W4​H3​+b4​)i=σ(W4i​H3​+b4i​).

And we can compute the gradient of columns of W4W_4W4​:

∂L(x0,y0)∂W4i=∑j=1o∂L(x0,y0)∂fj(x0)∂fj(x0)∂z∂z∂W4i=∑j=1o∂L(x0,y0)∂yj∂yj∂Hi∂Hi∂W4i=∑j=1o∂L∂yj∂ yj∂(WjH+bj)∂(WjH+bj)∂Hi∂(Hi)∂W4i=∑j=1l∂L∂yj σ′(WjH+bj) Wj,i σ′(W4iH3+b4i)H3,\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial W_4^i}= \sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial f^j (x_0)} \frac{\partial f^j (x_0)}{\partial z} \frac{\partial z}{\partial W_4^i} =\sum_{j=1}^{o}\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial y^j} \frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H^i} \frac{\partial H^i}{\partial W_4^i} \\ = \color{aqua}{ \sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j} \frac{\partial\, y^j}{\partial (W^jH+b^j)} \frac{\partial (W^jH+b^j)}{\partial H^{i}} \frac{\partial (H^{i})}{\partial W_4^i} } \\ = \sum_{j=1}^{l}\frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j}\,\sigma^{\prime}(W^j H+b^j)\,W^{j,i}\,\sigma^{\prime}(W^i_4 H_3+b^i_4)H_3, ∂W4i​∂L(x0​,y0​)​=j=1∑o​∂fj(x0​)∂L(x0​,y0​)​∂z∂fj(x0​)​∂W4i​∂z​=j=1∑o​∂yj∂L(x0​,y0​)​∂Hi∂yj​∂W4i​∂Hi​=j=1∑o​∂yj∂L​∂(WjH+bj)∂yj​∂Hi∂(WjH+bj)​∂W4i​∂(Hi)​=j=1∑l​∂yj∂L​σ′(WjH+bj)Wj,iσ′(W4i​H3​+b4i​)H3​,

where Wj,iW^{j,i}Wj,i is the iiith element of jjjth column in matrix WWW.

∂L(x0,y0)∂W3i=∑j=1o∂L(x0,y0)∂fj(x0)[∂fj(x0)∂z]∂z∂W3i=∑j=1o∂L∂yj[∂yj∂H3i]∂H3i∂W3i=∑j=1o∂L∂yj[∑k=1∂yj∂Hk∂Hk∂H3i]∂H3i∂W3i\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial W_3^i}=\sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial f^j (x_0)} [\frac{\partial f^j (x_0)}{\partial z}] \frac{\partial z}{\partial W_3^i} =\sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j } [\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H_3^i}] \frac{\partial H_3^i}{\partial W_3^i}\\ =\sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j } [\sum_{k=1}\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H^k} \frac{\partial H^k}{\partial H_3^i}] \frac{\partial H_3^i}{\partial W_3^i} ∂W3i​∂L(x0​,y0​)​=j=1∑o​∂fj(x0​)∂L(x0​,y0​)​[∂z∂fj(x0​)​]∂W3i​∂z​=j=1∑o​∂yj∂L​[∂H3i​∂yj​]∂W3i​∂H3i​​=j=1∑o​∂yj∂L​[k=1∑​∂Hk∂yj​∂H3i​∂Hk​]∂W3i​∂H3i​​

where all the partial derivatives or gradients have been computed or accessible. It is nothing except to add or multiply these values in the order when we compute the weights of hidden layer.

∂L(x0,y0)∂W2i=∑j=1o∂L(x0,y0)∂fj(x0)[∂fj(x0)∂z]∂z∂W2i=∑j=1l∂L∂yj[∂yj∂H2i]∂H2i∂W2i=∑j=1o∂L∂yj{∑k=1∂yj∂Hk[∑m∂Hk∂H3m∂H3m∂H2i]}∂H2i∂W2i\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial W_2^i}=\sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial f^j (x_0)} [\frac{\partial f^j (x_0)}{\partial z}] \frac{\partial z}{\partial W_2^i} =\sum_{j=1}^{l} \frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j } [\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H_2^i}] \frac{\partial H_2^i}{\partial W_2^i}\\ =\sum_{j=1}^{o} \frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j } \{\sum_{k=1}\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H^k} [\sum_{m}\frac{\partial H^k}{\partial H_3^m}\frac{\partial H_3^m}{\partial H_2^i}]\} \frac{\partial H_2^i}{\partial W_2^i} ∂W2i​∂L(x0​,y0​)​=j=1∑o​∂fj(x0​)∂L(x0​,y0​)​[∂z∂fj(x0​)​]∂W2i​∂z​=j=1∑l​∂yj∂L​[∂H2i​∂yj​]∂W2i​∂H2i​​=j=1∑o​∂yj∂L​{k=1∑​∂Hk∂yj​[m∑​∂H3m​∂Hk​∂H2i​∂H3m​​]}∂W2i​∂H2i​​

And the gradient of the first layer is computed by

∂L(x0,y0)∂W1i=∑j∂L(x0,y0)∂yj∂yj∂z∂z∂W1i=∑j∂L∂yj[∑k∂yj∂Hk∑m∂Hk∂H3m∑n∂H3k∂H2n∑r∂H2n∂H1r]∂H1i∂W1i.\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial W_1^i} =\sum_{j}\frac{\partial L(x_0,y_0)}{\partial y^j}\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial z}\frac{\partial z}{\partial W_1^i} \\ =\sum_{j}\frac{\partial L}{\partial y^j} [\sum_{k}\frac{\partial y^j}{\partial H^k} \sum_{m}\frac{\partial H^k}{\partial H_3^m} \sum_{n}\frac{\partial H_3^k}{\partial H_2^n} \sum_{r}\frac{\partial H_2^n}{\partial H_1^r}] \frac{\partial H_1^i}{\partial W_1^i}. ∂W1i​∂L(x0​,y0​)​=j∑​∂yj∂L(x0​,y0​)​∂z∂yj​∂W1i​∂z​=j∑​∂yj∂L​[k∑​∂Hk∂yj​m∑​∂H3m​∂Hk​n∑​∂H2n​∂H3k​​r∑​∂H1r​∂H2n​​]∂W1i​∂H1i​​.

Training Methods

The training is to find the optimal parameters of the model based on the training data set. The training methods are usually based on the gradient of cost function as well as back-propagation algorithm in deep learning. See Stochastic Gradient Descent in Numerical Optimization for details. In this section, we will talk other optimization tricks such as Normalization.

Concepts Interpretation
Overfitting and Underfitting See Overfitting or Overfitting and Underfitting With Machine Learning Algorithms
Memorization and Generalization Memorizing, given facts, is an obvious task in learning. This can be done by storing the input samples explicitly, or by identifying the concept behind the input data, and memorizing their general rules. The ability to identify the rules, to generalize, allows the system to make predictions on unknown data. Despite the strictly logical invalidity of this approach, the process of reasoning from specific samples to the general case can be observed in human learning. From https://www.teco.edu/~albrecht/neuro/html/node9.html.
Normalization and Standardization Normalization is to scale the data into the interval [0,1] while Standardization is to rescale the datum with zero mean 000 and unit variance 111. See Standardization vs. normalization.

Regularization

In mathematics, statistics, and computer science, particularly in the fields of machine learning and inverse problems, regularization is a process of introducing additional information in order to solve an ill-posed problem or to prevent overfitting. In general, regularization is a technique that applies to objective functions in ill-posed optimization problems. It changes the objective function or more generally the optimization procedure. However, it is not crystal clear that what is the relationship between the optimization techniques and generalization ability. See the following links for more information on optimization and generalization.

Parameter norm penalty

The ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm penalty is to add the squares of ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm of parameters to the objective function J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ) to reduce the parameters(or weights) as shown in ridge regression with regular term coefficient λ\lambdaλ, i.e. J(θ)+λ∥θ∥22.J(\theta)+\lambda {\|\theta\|}_{2}^{2}.J(θ)+λ∥θ∥22​. Suppose E(θ)=J(θ)+λ∥θ∥22E(\theta)=J(\theta)+\lambda {\|\theta\|}_{2}^{2}E(θ)=J(θ)+λ∥θ∥22​, the gradient descent take approximate (maybe inappropriate) form

θ=θ−η∂E(θ)∂θ=θ−η∂J(θ)∂θ−2ηλθ\theta=\theta-\eta\frac{\partial E(\theta)}{\partial \theta}=\theta -\eta\frac{\partial J(\theta)}{\partial \theta}-2\eta\lambda \theta θ=θ−η∂θ∂E(θ)​=θ−η∂θ∂J(θ)​−2ηλθ

thus

∂J(θ)∂θ=−2λθ  ⟹  J(θ)=e−2λθ.\frac{\partial J(\theta)}{\partial \theta}=-2\lambda\theta\implies J(\theta)=e^{-2\lambda \theta}. ∂θ∂J(θ)​=−2λθ⟹J(θ)=e−2λθ.

If we want to find the minima of E(θ)E(\theta)E(θ), θ\thetaθ will decay to 000. It extends to the following iterative formula:

θt+1=(1−λ)θt−αt∂J(θt)∂θ,\theta^{t+1} = (1-\lambda)\theta^{t}-\alpha_{t}\frac{\partial J(\theta^{t})}{\partial \theta}, θt+1=(1−λ)θt−αt​∂θ∂J(θt)​,

where λ\lambdaλ determines how you trade off the original cost J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ) with the large weights penalization. The new term λ\lambdaλ coming from the regularization causes the weight to decay in proportion to its size.

  • https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/70101/neural-networks-weight-change-momentum-and-weight-decay
  • https://metacademy.org/graphs/concepts/weight_decay_neural_networks
  • https://machinelearningmastery.com/how-to-reduce-overfitting-in-deep-neural-networks-with-weight-constraints-in-keras/
  • https://machinelearningmastery.com/how-to-reduce-overfitting-in-deep-learning-with-weight-regularization/

The ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ norm penalty is also used in deep learning as in LASSO. It is to solve the following optimization problem:

min⁡θJ(θ)+λ∥θ∥1,\min_{\theta}J(\theta)+\lambda{\|\theta\|}_1, θmin​J(θ)+λ∥θ∥1​,

where λ\lambdaλ is a hyperparameter. Sparsity brings to the model as shown as in LASSO.

Early stop

Its essential is to make a balance in memorization and generalization. Early stopping is to stop the procedure before finding the minima of cost in training data. It is one direct application of cross validation.

Dropout

It is to cripple the connections stochastically, which is often used in visual tasks. See the original paper Dropout: A Simple Way to Prevent Neural Networks from Overfitting.

Data Augmentation

Data augmentation is to augment the training datum specially in visual recognition. Overfitting in supervised learning is data-dependent. In other words, the model may generalize better if the data set is more diverse. It is to collect more datum in the statistical perspective.

  • The Effectiveness of Data Augmentation in Image Classification using Deep Learning

Convolutional Neural Network

Convolutional neural network is originally aimed to solve visual tasks. In so-called Three Giants' Survey, the history of ConvNet and deep learning is curated. Deep, Deep Trouble--Deep Learning’s Impact on Image Processing, Mathematics, and Humanity tells us the mathematicians' impression on ConvNet in image processing.

Convolutional layer

Convolutional layer consists of padding, convolution, pooling.

Convolution Operation

Convolution operation is the basic element of convolution neural network. We only talk the convolution operation in 2-dimensional space.

The image is represented as matrix or tensor in computer:

M=(x11x12x13⋯x1nx21x22x23⋯x2n⋮⋮⋮⋱⋮xm1xm2xm3⋯xmn)M=\begin{pmatrix} x_{11} & x_{12} & x_{13} & \cdots & x_{1n} \\ x_{21} & x_{22} & x_{23} & \cdots & x_{2n} \\ \vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ x_{m1} & x_{m2} & x_{m3} & \cdots & x_{mn} \\ \end{pmatrix} M=⎝⎜⎜⎜⎜⎛​x11​x21​⋮xm1​​x12​x22​⋮xm2​​x13​x23​⋮xm3​​⋯⋯⋱⋯​x1n​x2n​⋮xmn​​⎠⎟⎟⎟⎟⎞​

where each entry xij∈{1,2⋯ ,256},i∈{1,2,⋯ ,m},j∈{1,2,⋯ ,n}x_{ij}\in\{1,2\cdots,256\},i\in\{1,2,\cdots,m\},j\in\{1,2,\cdots,n\}xij​∈{1,2⋯,256},i∈{1,2,⋯,m},j∈{1,2,⋯,n}.

  • Transformation as matrix multiplication
    • The MMM under the transformation AAA is their product -MAMAMA- of which each column is the linear combination of columns of the matrix MMM. The spatial information or the relationship of the neighbors is lost.
  • Spatial information extraction
    • Kernel in image processing takes the relationship of the neighboring entries into consideration. It transforms the neighboring entries into one real value. In 2-dimenional space, convolution corresponds to doubly block circulant matrix\color{aqua}{\text{doubly block circulant matrix}}doubly block circulant matrix if the matrix is flatten. It is local pattern that we can learn.
The illustration of convolution operator
(http://cs231n.github.io/assets/conv-demo/index.html)

As similar as the inner product of vector, the convolution operators can compute the similarity between the submatrix of images and the kernels (also called filters). The convolution operators play the role as parameter sharing and local connection. For more information on CNN, click the following links.

  • CNN(卷积神经网络)是什么？有入门简介或文章吗？ - 机器之心的回答 - 知乎
  • 能否对卷积神经网络工作原理做一个直观的解释？ - YJango的回答 - 知乎
  • One by one convolution
  • conv arithmetic
  • Convolution deep learning

Padding

The standard convolution operation omit the information of the boundaries. Padding is to add some 000s outside the boundaries of the images.

Zero padding

https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/36278093

Activation

As in feedforward neural networks, an additional non-linear operation called ReLU has been used after every Convolution operation.

Pooling as Subsampling

Pooling as a special convolution is to make the model/network more robust.

Max Pooling

It is to use the maximum to represent the local information.

See https://www.superdatascience.com/convolutional-neural-networks-cnn-step-2-max-pooling/.

Sum Pooling

It is to use the sum to represent the local information.

Average Pooling

It is to use the average to represent the local information.

Random Pooling

It is to draw a sample from the receptive field to represent the local information. https://www.cnblogs.com/tornadomeet/p/3432093.html

CNN

Convolution neural network (conv-net or CNN for short) is the assembly of convolution, padding, pooling and full connection , such as

M→Conv1H1→Conv2H2…→ConvlH→σy.M\stackrel{Conv 1}{\to}H_1 \stackrel{Conv 2}{\to} H_2 \dots \stackrel{Conv l}{\to}{H} \stackrel{\sigma}{\to} y. M→Conv1H1​→Conv2H2​…→ConvlH→σy.

In the iiith layer of convolutional neural network, it can be expressed as

Hi~=Ci⊗(P⊕Hi−1)Hi=Pooling⋅(σ∘Hi~)\tilde{H_i}=C_i\otimes(P\oplus H_{i-1}) \\ H_i = Pooling\cdot (\sigma\circ \tilde{H_i}) Hi​~​=Ci​⊗(P⊕Hi−1​)Hi​=Pooling⋅(σ∘Hi​~​)

where ⊗,⊕,⋅\otimes,\oplus,\cdot⊗,⊕,⋅ represent convolution operation, padding and pooling, respectively.

Recurrent Neural Networks and Long Short-Time Memory

Recurrent neural networks are aimed to handle sequence data such as time series. Recall the recursive form of feedforward neural networks:

\begin{align} \mathbf{z}_i &= W_i H_{i-1}+b_i, \\ H_{i} &= \sigma\circ(\mathbf{z}_i), \end{align}

where Wi∈Rli×li−1W_i\in\mathbb{R}^{l_{i}\times l_{i-1}}Wi​∈Rli​×li−1​, Hi(as well as bi)∈Rli∀i∈{1,2,…,D}H_i (\text{as well as}\, b_i)\in \mathbb{R}^{l_i}\forall i\in\{1, 2, \dots, D\}Hi​(as well asbi​)∈Rli​∀i∈{1,2,…,D} and σ\sigmaσ is activation function. In convention, H0H_0H0​ is defined as input X∈RpX\in\mathbb{R}^{p}X∈Rp. In short, the formula in the iiith layer of feedforward neural network is given by

Hi=σ∘(WiHi−1+bi).H_i=\sigma\circ(W_i H_{i-1}+b_i). Hi​=σ∘(Wi​Hi−1​+bi​).

It may suit the identically independently distributed data set. However, the sequence data is not identically independently distributed in most cases. For example, the outcome of current decision determines the next decision. In mathematics it can be expressed as

Ht=σ∘(Xt,Ht−1)=σ∘(WHt−1+UXt+b),H_{t}=\sigma\circ(X_t,H_{t-1})=\sigma\circ(W H_{t-1} + U X_{t}+b), Ht​=σ∘(Xt​,Ht−1​)=σ∘(WHt−1​+UXt​+b),

where Xt∈RpX_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{p}Xt​∈Rp is the output ∀t∈{1,2…,τ}\forall t\in\{1,2\dots,\tau\}∀t∈{1,2…,τ}.

RNN Cell

For each step from t=1t=1t=1 to t=τt=\taut=τ, the complete update equations of RNN:

\begin{align} H_{t} &=\sigma\circ(W H_{t-1} + U X_{t} + b) \\ O_{t} &= \mathrm{softmax}(V H_{t} + c) \end{align}

where the parameters are the bias vectors bbb and ccc along with the weight matrices UUU, VVV and WWW, respectively for input-to-hidden, hidden-to-output and hidden-to-hidden connections.

Types of RNN
(https://www.altoros.com/blog/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Deep-Learning-Using-TensorFlow-recurrent-neural-networks.png)

Bi-directional RNN

For each step from t=1t=1t=1 to t=τt = \taut=τ, the complete update equations of RNN:

\begin{align} \stackrel{\rightarrow}H_{t} &=\sigma\circ(W_1\stackrel{\rightarrow}H_{t-1}+U_1X_{t}+b_1) \\ \stackrel{\leftarrow}H_{t} &=\sigma\circ(W_2\stackrel{\leftarrow}H_{t+1}+U_2X_{t}+b_2) \\ O_{t} &= \mathrm{softmax}(VH_{t}+c) \end{align}

where Ht=[H→t;H←t]H_{t} = [\stackrel{\rightarrow} H_{t};\stackrel{\leftarrow} H_{t}]Ht​=[H→​t​;H←​t​].

Bi-directional RNN

LSTM

There are several architectures of LSTM units. A common architecture is composed of a memory cell, an input gate, an output gate and a forget gate. It is the first time to solve the gradient vanishing problem and long-term dependencies in deep learning.

LSTM block
See LSTM block at(https://devblogs.nvidia.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/LSTM.png)
  • forget gate ft=σ(Wf[ht−1,xt]+bf)f_{t}=\sigma(W_{f}[h_{t-1},x_t]+b_f)ft​=σ(Wf​[ht−1​,xt​]+bf​)
  • input gate it=σ(Wi[ht−1,xt]+bi)i_{t}=\sigma(W_i[h_{t-1},x_t]+b_i)it​=σ(Wi​[ht−1​,xt​]+bi​), C~t=tanh(WC[ht−1,xt]+bC)\tilde{C}_{t}=tanh(W_C[h_{t-1},x_t]+b_C)C~t​=tanh(WC​[ht−1​,xt​]+bC​)
  • memory cell ct=ft×ct−1+it×C~tc_{t}=f_t\times c_{t-1}+i_{t}\times{\tilde{C}_{t}}ct​=ft​×ct−1​+it​×C~t​
  • output gate Ot=σ(WO[ht−1,xt]+bO)O_{t}=\sigma(W_{O}[h_{t-1},x_t]+b_{O})Ot​=σ(WO​[ht−1​,xt​]+bO​) and ht=Ot×tanh(ct)h_{t}=O_{t}\times tanh(c_{t})ht​=Ot​×tanh(ct​)

Deep RNN

Deep RNN is composed of RNN cell as MLP is composed of perceptrons. For each step from t=1t=1t=1 to t=τt=\taut=τ, the complete update equations of deep ddd-RNN at the iiith layer:

\begin{align} H_{t}^{i} &=\sigma\circ(W_{i} H_{t-1} + U_{i} X_{t} + b) \\ O_{t} &= \mathrm{softmax}(V H_{d} + c) \end{align}

where the parameters are the bias vectors bbb and ccc along with the weight matrices UiU_iUi​, VVV and WiW_iWi​, respectively for input-to-hidden, hidden-to-output and hidden-to-hidden connections for i∈{1,2,⋯ ,d}i\in \{1,2,\cdots,d\}i∈{1,2,⋯,d}.

Other RNN cells also can compose deep RNN via this stacking way such as deep Bi-RNN networks.

Attention Mechanism

An attention model is a method that takes nnn arguments y1,…,yny_1, \dots, y_ny1​,…,yn​ and a context ccc. It return a vector zzz which is supposed to be the summary of the yi∈Rd{y}_i\in \mathbb{R}^{d}yi​∈Rd, focusing on information linked to the context ccc. More formally, it returns a weighted arithmetic mean of the yiy_iyi​, and the weights are chosen according the relevance of each yiy_iyi​ given the context ccc. In mathematics, it can be expressed as:

αi=softmax(s(yi,c))z=∑i=1nαiyi{\alpha}_i = softmax(s(y_i,c)) \\ z = \sum_{i=1}^{n} {\alpha}_i y_i αi​=softmax(s(yi​,c))z=i=1∑n​αi​yi​

where s(⋅,⋅)s(\cdot, \cdot)s(⋅,⋅) is the attention scoring function. The attention scoring function s(yi,c)s({y}_i, c)s(yi​,c) is diverse, such as:

  • the additive model s(yi,c)=vTtanh∘(Wyi+Uc)s({y}_i, c) = v^{T} tanh\circ (W {y}_i + U c)s(yi​,c)=vTtanh∘(Wyi​+Uc), where v∈Rdv \in \mathbb{R}^{d}v∈Rd, W∈Rd×dW \in \mathbb{R}^{d\times d}W∈Rd×d, U∈RdU \in \mathbb{R}^{d}U∈Rd are parameters to learn;
  • the inner product model s(yi,c)=<yi,c>s({y}_i, c) = \left< {y}_i, c \right>s(yi​,c)=⟨yi​,c⟩, i.e. the inner product of yi,c{y}_i, cyi​,c;
  • the scaled inner product model s(yi,c)=<yi,c>ds({y}_i, c) = \frac{\left< {y}_i, c \right>}{d}s(yi​,c)=d⟨yi​,c⟩​,where ddd is the dimension of input yi{y}_iyi​;
  • the bilinear model s(yi,c)=yiTWcs({y}_i, c) = {y}_i^{T} W cs(yi​,c)=yiT​Wc, where W∈Rd×dW\in \mathbb{R}^{d\times d}W∈Rd×d is parameter matrix to learn.

It is always as one component of some complex network as normalization.

Graph Convolution Network

Graph can be represented as adjacency matrix as shown in Graph Algorithm. However, the adjacency matrix only describe the connections between the nodes. The feature of the nodes does not appear. The node itself really matters. A naive approach is to concatenate the feature matrix X∈RN×EX\in \mathbb{R}^{N\times E}X∈RN×E and adjacency matrix A∈RN×NA\in \mathbb{R}^{N\times N}A∈RN×N, i.e. Xin=[X,A]∈RN×(N+E)X_{in}=[X, A]\in \mathbb{R}^{N\times (N+E)}Xin​=[X,A]∈RN×(N+E). And what is the output?

How can deep learning apply to them?

For these models, the goal is then to learn a function of signals/features on a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) which takes as input:

  • A feature description xix_ixi​ for every node iii; summarized in a N×DN\times DN×D feature matrix XXX (NNN: number of nodes, DDD: number of input features)
  • A representative description of the graph structure in matrix form; typically in the form of an adjacency matrix AAA (or some function thereof)

and produces a node-level output ZZZ (an N×FN\times FN×F feature matrix, where FFF is the number of output features per node). Graph-level outputs can be modeled by introducing some form of pooling operation (see, e.g. Duvenaud et al., NIPS 2015).

Every neural network layer can then be written as a non-linear function

Hi+1=σ∘(Hi,A){H}_{i+1} = \sigma \circ ({H}_{i}, A) Hi+1​=σ∘(Hi​,A)

with H0=Xin{H}_0 = {X}_{in}H0​=Xin​ and Hd=Z{H}_{d} = ZHd​=Z (or ZZZ for graph-level outputs), ddd being the number of layers. The specific models then differ only in how σ\sigmaσ is chosen and parameterized.

For example, we can consider a simple form of a layer-wise propagation rule

Hi+1=σ∘(Hi,A)=σ∘(AHiWi){H}_{i+1} = \sigma \circ ({H}_{i}, A)=\sigma \circ(A {H}_{i} {W}_{i}) Hi+1​=σ∘(Hi​,A)=σ∘(AHi​Wi​)

where Wi{W}_{i}Wi​ is a weight matrix for the iii-th neural network layer and σ(⋅)\sigma (\cdot)σ(⋅) is is a non-linear activation function such as ReLU.

  • But first, let us address two limitations of this simple model: multiplication with AAA means that, for every node, we sum up all the feature vectors of all neighboring nodes but not the node itself (unless there are self-loops in the graph). We can "fix" this by enforcing self-loops in the graph: we simply add the identity matrix III to AAA.

  • The second major limitation is that AAA is typically not normalized and therefore the multiplication with AAA will completely change the scale of the feature vectors (we can understand that by looking at the eigenvalues of AAA).Normalizing AAA such that all rows sum to one, i.e. D−1AD^{−1}AD−1A, where DDD is the diagonal node degree matrix, gets rid of this problem.

In fact, the propagation rule introduced in Kipf & Welling (ICLR 2017) is given by:

Hi+1=σ∘(Hi,A)=σ∘(D^−12A^D^−12HiWi),{H}_{i+1} = \sigma \circ ({H}_{i}, A)=\sigma \circ(\hat{D}^{-\frac{1}{2}} \hat{A} \hat{D}^{-\frac{1}{2}} {H}_{i} {W}_{i}), Hi+1​=σ∘(Hi​,A)=σ∘(D^−21​A^D^−21​Hi​Wi​),

with A^=A+I\hat{A}=A+IA^=A+I, where III is the identity matrix and D^\hat{D}D^ is the diagonal node degree matrix of A^\hat{A}A^.

See more details at Multi-layer Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) with first-order filters.

Probabilistic Programming and Topological Data Analysis

Probabilistic Graphical Model

A graphical model or probabilistic graphical model (PGM) or structured probabilistic model is a probabilistic model for which a graph expresses the conditional dependence structure between random variables. They are commonly used in probability theory, statistics—particularly Bayesian statistics—and machine learning. It is a marriage of graph theory and probability theory.
